pros: Total compensation is great! Pay is fair for customer service. Very warm and welcoming environment. Managers are supportive and provide fact based feedback.
cons: Mandatory Overtime. Can be hard to get holidays off. Hard to move out of Shareholder Services if you don't have any other skills.

headline: Simply Stellar place to work
pros: The benefits, and compensation are amazing but the best part is the attitude of leadership and everyone else. The training program is very thorough.
cons: Can be a culture shock. There training is not evenly paced and can cause you to lose interest. Spends too much time on unimportant areas and not enough on the important stuff

headline: Review
pros: Culture, investment process, tenure, associates
cons: Group decision making upon occasion slow.

pros: It was great at first, great people.
cons: Management not great, favortism amongst employees and management. The systems that are set in place are not clear to allow the employee to be successful.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: It's a company that really cares about its people. They are extremely careful about who they hire, have a strong culture of respect and collaboration and outstanding benefits.
cons: Sometimes the collaborative environment can make it feel like it takes forever to get buy-in for a new idea.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great collaboration within group and amazing people to work with.
cons: Things happen at a slow pace at times.

headline: Great Starter Job
pros: At the beginning there was room to grow
cons: Micromanagement and poor training are killing the customer service department

headline: Lowsy senior management
pros: Good pay.  Bonuses are great.  Associates are all really nice.  I'm just typing words now to meet the 20 word min.
cons: Bad senior management and worse upper management.  Outsources any chance they get.  Rarely hires managers from internal candidates.  No upward growth.

headline: Lots of perks
pros: Collaborative work environment, which allowed associates to share and implement best practices.
cons: Tax season is grueling but always a sense of accomplishment once it has ended.

headline: Good place to gain experience
pros: Great place to learn the industry and gain valuable skills.  There many great people that work there and can be a fun environment to work in at times.
cons: Below average compensation.  Professional growth is limited over time.  Organization resists change and is slow to innovate.  They try to foster a good corporate culture, but fall short often.

headline: Toxic
pros: They pay you and certain offices benefit from the firm's deep pockets.
cons: If you watched the movie the Stepford Wives and thought it looked like a nice place to live, CG is for you.   Avoid any department except for the investment group because you will be micro-managed into a state of numbness. When they decide it's time to manage you out, they make your life a living nightmare.  Creativity is viewed as disruptive and the only way to succeed is to check greater aspirations at the door.   The organization manages to mediocrity.

headline: Research Associate
pros: Unrivaled people culture. One of the best places to work in the asset management industry.
cons: Firm culture disproportionately set by Investment professionals.

headline: Portfolio Control analyst
pros: Good retirement benefits. Collegial environment. Respect for individuals. Private company. Diverse. High caliber of people.
cons: Lack of career opportunities and progression. Wish they would use similar titles (e.g. VP, MD) to investment banks like Goldman...but very flat.

headline: Premier Employer
pros: The Company invests in its current employees by training them on new technologies instead of laying them off and hiring from the outside. Excellent benefits.  The company puts 15% of employee's yearly salary into a master retirement plan and pays 2 yearly bonuses to every associate down to the mailroom worker.
cons: current CIO IT strategy is to supplement workforce by hiring outsourcing firms and alot of the workers are  not very experienced or competent.  This puts alot more stress on associates to train and retrain new outsourced associates because of the high turnover.  Sometimes I think penny smart and pound foolish.

headline: Area Sales Rep
pros: Great health insurance, good salary.
cons: Micro Management, hard to advance

headline: Retirement Plan Service Representative
pros: Great benefits, in depth training, friendly co-workers. Campus is amazing too (on-site cafe)! Managers are attentive, willing to listen to ideas.
cons: I have not been with the company long enough to have experienced any cons. It is a cubicle environment, that is off-putting to some.

headline: Senior Accountant
pros: Great Benefits(long vesting period though), flexible schedule, cafeteria, good locations
cons: Poor development plans for long term growth, management disconnected from overall production  activities. Desperate for people so they lie at times to get people in. High volume of low EQ individuals.

headline: Senior Accountant/Associate
pros:
- great benefits
- Good pay
cons:
- Terrible management
- Too much politics
- Extremely procedures oriented and by the book
- Limited capacity to grow
- Limited ability to think outside the box
- One mistake can cost you dearly

headline: Great Company
pros: They treat you well as far as compensation and benefits. Management is very involved in associate development. Open door policy.
cons: Low chance of moving up in the company quickly. Company is big on cross training and lateral moves without a pay raise with new responsibilities.

headline: Senior Test Engineer
pros: Awesome Company to work with
cons: No Comments about the company

headline: client service representative
pros: Great working conditions.  Supportive management for the most part.  Great team.  Benefits (vacation, health & wellness) were truly excellent.  I haven't seen retirement benefits like this offered anywhere else.
cons: Easy to get stuck in one position for a long time.  Not easy to transfer to other areas of the company of even transfer to another area (cross train) within the service dept.  This does lead to boredom and burnout.  It's a luck of the draw on whether or not you get matched with a great team lead or an aweful one.

headline: Investment
pros: Standout culture, decentralized decision making.
cons: It is a large firm, has to be your cup of tea.

headline: Senior Software Developer
pros: Good compensation in health, bonuses based on company performance and individual performance, and free money to invest in American Funds.
cons: Small salary increases around 2-3.5% annual.  Extremely hard to get to specialist title after senior title.

headline: Great place to be
pros: work-life balance, low turnover, top tier paying employers, plenty of room to grow
cons: high tenure of most employees results in complacency and lack of ambition among certain groups

headline: capital group
pros: positive anvironment friendly helpful coworkers
cons: majority of shifts are 10am-7pm

headline: Workmanagement Analyst
pros:
Excellent benefits and caring culture.
Honing my skills in managing operations while telecommuting.
Mentoring and developing team members comprised of 4 specialists.
Leading projects and end-user testing.
cons: Limited variety in work shifts for full-time associates.

headline: Great Place
pros: compensation is great. MRP is good.
cons: SLower to promote and grow employees.

headline: OK to learn
pros: Learn a lot about fin services and asset mgmt.
cons: Stressful at times, overworked but overall OK nothing too bad.

headline: Good company, cumbersome hiring process
pros: Great company in a tough industry. Very smart investment advisors.
cons: Hiring process is very time consuming and needs serious streamlining. They lose excellent qualified candidates due to their unusually long interview and hiring cycle.

headline: Great company
pros: It s a great company to be în, with lots of opportunities to rotate internally, depending în your preference. Great colleagues and great managers.
cons: Quite conservative environment, with not too much exposure on the European market.

headline: Associate
pros:
Culture, intelligence of everyone, management, benefits

Capital Group is significantly difference than most companies in the financial services industry. The people are supportive and interesting.
cons:
Formal, slow moving

It takes along time to turn an idea into fruition. I think it has to do with the fact that the company is private.

headline: A Strange Echo Chamber
pros: Great benefits and facilities, decent pay, standard business hours and paid holidays/vacation, etc.
cons: Entire company exists in a bubble that ignores the rest of the world. Best practices and new technology are completely disregarded in favor of developing in-house solutions. People who have been with the company for their entire careers have no idea how things work at other companies. Rate of advancement and pay increases are based on the assumption that all workers will remain at Capital for their entire careers, which is not how the world works in the 21st century.

headline: Shareholders Services
pros: Very Good atmosphere to work in, the supervisors give lots of good feedback and are always willing to help with any problem.
cons: The early morning start times are a little hard to get used to

headline: Equity Research Associate
pros: exposure to great investors and investor discussion.
cons: experience depends on the analysts you are supporting. no mobility.

headline: Analysis and distribution of results, competitor comparisons, attribution and marketing material
pros: Variety of work, encouraged to seek area of specialism, opinions welcome, exceptional culture
cons: Slow to progress processes, meetings overkill, lack of structure, heavy workload and responsibilities

headline: Senior Client Service Representative
pros: Great Work Atmosphere, Great Management
cons: Unfortunately, closed the Scottsdale site.  Would have stayed through retirement however did not wish to relocate.

headline: Client Representative Senior
pros: competitive pay and benefits package
cons: no uniformity in management from one team to another in shareholder services department.

headline: Externship
pros: Everyone was very kind and helpful
cons: They didn't let you pick who you desk side shadowed so I was shadowing an accountant doing IT and I know nothing about IT

headline: Client Service Representative
pros: I love this job many pro's from benefits to hours to pay and much more. Work life balance is great.
cons: None. I don't have any well except how long the process to get in and hired is. It can be a long process.

headline: Good company
pros:
Performance and yearly bonuses
Good work environment and pay
Company supports development
Good work/life balance
cons:
Company outsourced IT for costs
Extremely talented people were let go

headline: Portfolio Control Analyst
pros: Good benefits. Not much else.
cons: Very little advancement opportunities. Managers do not help to develop associates.

headline: Specialist
pros: Associates are treated with tremendous respect. Salary and benefits are excellent. There are MANY opportunities for advancement for hard workers who care and are a good fit for the company.
cons: Takes way too long to let people go. Very disheartening.

headline: Typical large finance company
pros: Good pay, benefits, bonus structure. Overall they treat employees pretty well. In general people are very cordial (at least on the outside) to each other, so you rarely see arguments or escalated conversations (although it might all happen behind the scenes)
cons: Too many middle managers- you need to invest heavily in politics to be successful here. Definitely feel like you are being micromanaged- any small mistake you make will cost you heavily during review time. Very risk-adverse culture. You will also likely take a title cut here.

headline: New Employee
pros: very work & family life balanced
cons: none that I know of yet.

headline: SR Associate
pros: Benefits and health care plan are good
cons: Unfortunately, it is who you know and who's butt you kiss. In all honesty, the really hard working, respectful, honest people either got laid off in 2014 or the few that are left are the minority. Managers really do NOT know how to manage people---glorified titles and layers upon layers of them. Integrity went away in 2014. Now a lot of contractors who cannot measure up to the quality and dedication of the people who are no longer here. Even a lot of the permanent associates think they are owed something and many have an ego so huge. They gossip, work at 60% capacity, lunch and texting time are more important to them than getting the work out---and managers let it slide. Too bad it has come to this. Promoting some from within just because their manager and them can gossip all day and they are friends is ot the way JBL and some of the higher ups would like it to be. If they only knew.....

headline: Excellent place to work
pros:
Competitive salary, good benefits.
Driven workforce, all aspiring to do the right thing.
cons: Slow moving at time.  People have been here for many years which can impact promotion opportunities.

headline: Portfolio Control
pros: Interesting company to work for with plenty of exposure given to those who seek it
cons: pay could be better. It's often the chosen few who really benefit

headline: Operations
pros: Great benefits great working hours 8-5 Monday to Friday. Great long term employer. Many perks like bonuses and community involvement. Also good vacation benefits. On-site gym and cafe, plus under ground parking.
cons: Upward movement depends on your manger so hope you have a good manager, training is lacking for some depts. Very structured and not quick to change.

headline: Capital Group
pros: If you are willing to work in a call center environment, hands down best company to work for.
cons: Can take a long time to grow within the company. Very strict on attendance when it comes to progression within company.

headline: Solid Benefits/Horrible Culture
pros: Thorough training and solid 401K/benefits
cons: Treat you like a child. Mandatory Overtime for a over a year, even for employees who already work 10 hour days.

headline: TAP Intern
pros: Personal attention, focused on professional development, valuable feedback and training, strong company culture
cons: Could have had more training for how to manage one's manager

headline: Seems like (and is presented as) the "perfect" job...until you dig a little deeper and get some time under your belt.
pros: Good benefits, open door policy with all levels of management, overall positive morale among employees, business casual dress code (allowed to wear jeans everyday), great food at on-site café, covered parking garage, decent PTO accrual, insurance from day one, thorough paid training program.
cons: Undesirable shift schedule, months at a time of mandatory overtime, adults who act like children who like to "tell on one another" for ridiculous reasons, many poor managers, the deepest micro-management I've ever encountered in 40+ years of professional experience in similar settings, 85% of positions are nothing more than fast-paced call center jobs (but not presented as such until you're done with training and actually on the floor, odd culture that is difficult to adapt to...regardless of your personality/experience, very limited potential for growth or diversion from phone positions, "he-said/she said" scenarios still get put in your file, even if there are no grounds for it or proof it occurred, poor staffing causes  internal workflow roadblocks, management plays favorites and personal merit is clouded/varies from different associates and management, easily fixable problems are ignored, even when identified as such and agreed upon...yet nothing is done to fix/improve them, complaints about management causes retaliation (even though it's promised you are protected from it), boasts of importance of work/life balance to the company is quite the opposite, I could go on and on. If you learn to bite your lip and just deal with these negatives, it can be a lucrative career if you don't mind being stuck in similar positions and lateral "promotions" for years at a time. It's one of those companies that you can easily point out the cons, but they somehow keep you there with their "Kool-Aid"!

headline: They favor butt kissers
pros: Benefits no weekends that's about it
cons: It's not what you know it's who you know

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
Smart colleagues, Great work life balance
flexible work arrangements
collaborative culture
caring managers
interesting work
stable company
cons: none -  it has bene great so far

headline: Make it a great company for yourself
pros: Work life balance is really a thing with American Funds/CG. Benefits are fantastic, and the overall compensation is easily at the top of their industry.
cons: Slow moving company. Be careful not to pigeon hole yourself, and always be mindful of opportunities around you. Take proactive charge of your career path, and do not rely on anyone else.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work. Loved the culture and everything about the way they did business.
cons: Limited opportunities for movement as the organization is pretty flat.

headline: Capital Group
pros: Good benefits, work/life balance encouraged (if you make that happen yourself), flexible start time (for some positions), regular communication from upper management about state of company, monetary bonuses if company does well, nice people to work with
cons: Too much change occurring at one time that process and workflow gets confusing, sloppy and some begin to not care, and some decisions in some depts made without thoroughly reviewing workflow and dept needs.

headline: Capital Group
pros: Great people and great benefits.
cons: Middle of the road pay and upward mobility

headline: Perspectives Beware
pros: The facilities are amazing and the Café is really nice and has good food and good prices.  The location is good and you don't have to fight traffic to pull in and out of the campus.  The scrum rooms are nice and are set up for efficiency and productivity.  There are break rooms everywhere.  with ice machines, coffee, fridges and microwaves.
cons:
The environment was harsh because of the sensitive culture that is encouraged.  There is no criticism, joking or asking hard to answer questions.  The team I was on had allot of insecurity about the technology being used, insecurity in general about the project.  They did not like a new comer having new ideas or suggestions.  They do not like you asking for clarification because you are new and need further insight so you can ramp up to speed.  They will misinterpret everything you say and look for ways that could be interpreted as talking down to people.  They take things out of context and report you for a single sentence you said that was part of a larger conversation, because they believe it to be insulting.  In short you have to be careful with everything you do and say.  They have meetings to prepare for meetings.  They have too many meetings, which gives a developer about 2 hours to develop if they are lucky.  Projects will move along at a snails pace with no since of urgency.  If you try to help move it along you are not being a team player.  If you do not agree with everyone else's opinion you are not being a team player.  If you express opinions, do prototyping, ask questions to the product owner of clarification you are seen as trying to make yourself more important than anyone else on the team and will be reminded that you are not anymore important than anyone else and the project is the most important thing.  They say they buy into whole team ownership of the code but then will be told that if you need to modify someone else's code that you need to talk to the author first and get permission.  If you point out issues in the code that could result in issues later they will think you are being critical.  If you point out issues where other's are not conforming to coding standards, they will think you are being critical.  They will think your trying to prove yourself when all your doing is trying to do your job when you do not care about impressing anyone, all you want to do is work and to feel like you contributed.  

Onboarding was a nightmare.  I was promised that I would be given briefings on the architecture. I was promised that I would get to shadow others to learn the business, code and project.  I was given a brief demo and explanation of the project that was being rewritten, and that was it.  I spent the rest of my time reading going to meetings to prepare for other meetings.  No one had time to help me because of meetings that left them to complete their assigned tasks.  Other people's time is limited because of meetings, so being able to shadow and get a full understanding of your project may not happen.

headline: Manager
pros: Great benefits and pay.  Excellent retirement plan. Wonderful culture and environment.
cons: The organization has changed over the years and is not the same as it was years ago.  Hopefully the senior business leaders will listen to their people and work to return the environment to where it was.

headline: Client Services Specialist Senior
pros: Good culture, great benefits, fantastic retirement!
cons: Very flat organization. Hard to move our of client services area, especially as an associate.

headline: Team Manager
pros: Supportive and engaged leadership creates an easy going yet focused and productive work environment. Recruits high caliber talent. Offers competitive salary, benefits and generous bonuses.
cons: Forecasting methods, planning and distribution of work result in challenges to consistently meet service levels, which adds pressure on associates to complete work, resulting in intraday additional time.

headline: It's a steady job with very good benefits.
pros:
Starting compensation is good.
Benefits are great.
Managers know you by name.
cons:
It's very much a call center.
Work is redundant and uninteresting.
There's very little opportunity for advancement. Promotions seem to be handed to certain individuals despite being offered to "everyone eligible."

headline: Client Services Manager
pros: Incredible people, benefits and culture.
cons: Closing the PHO site in June

headline: Challenging work. Great people
pros: Really smart, motivated people. Good benefits and work/life balance.
cons: Some really bad managers that should be fired. Don't let go of bad employees quick enough

headline: Horrible
pros: It's better than nothing and the cafeteria is amazing. However, that's the absolute end of positivity from this business that is run like a current day slave plantation.
cons: Very discriminatory against their large percentage of temporary employees. They must use a servants entrance and are looked down upon those who are permanent including management.

headline: Not the same Capital as before
pros: Clean offices, nice coworkers, cafe on site
cons: Required overtime is out of control, morale is low as ever, incompetent team managers do nothing but micromanage their day away, development only for certain associates

headline: Good company
pros:
Good Benefits
Nice office environment
Friendly coworkers
Established Company
cons:
Frequently changing management
Frequent office desk relocations
Concerns about job security

headline: OK..
pros: The pay was pretty good if you worked 40+ hours a week
cons: The hours weren't all that great

headline: Lead Analyst
pros: The core values are the basis for many of the decisions within the company
cons: The company will hire from outside even when there are qualified associates within the company

headline: Advisor Marketing/Client Services Sr
pros: Great company, great associates. There are a lot of perks that we take for granted. A very generous retirement plan. Lots of complaints of no promotions, but on day one if you let your manager know what you want to do and what your goals are, they will work with you to get you there. There's a lot of good training, and you will be the among the most knowledgeable in the industry
cons: The good training leads to high turnover because the pay does not increase with your training/responsibilities. Two months of training for an additional role, no pay increase. Two weeks of training for an additional role, no pay increase. They are basically a farm system for other mutual fund/wealth management companies because other companies know how much you know, and will pay you more to work for them

headline: Great Place to work
pros: very relaxed environment. pay employees to stay and get fit. company help pay for undergrad. freedom to think on your own.
cons: poor work and home balance. tons of req overtime. promotions come far and in-between. customers can be rude and very call center based job.

headline: Worst company EVER
pros: Get weekends off but that's for any other job too although they force everyone to come in at 6am and stay til 4pm every month end
cons: Horrible office morale, constant lay offs, no structure or stability what's so ever, start company without a vision or goal. People talking behind each others backs, management constantly tells lies, just overall a horrible place to work for.

headline: Retirement Plan Sales Consultant
pros: Great place to work and career opportunities, to a degree.
cons: Glass ceiling and favoritism abound.

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros: We are fortunate to receive a June & December Bonus, generous MRP, and good salaries.
cons: No room for promotions, no work life balance anymore, micro-managing and picking apart everything we do. Always a suggestion of what you should do better instead of "good job". The SHSV morale is at the lowest and clearly we do not have enough associates to handle the volumes and are lacking in strong experienced associates.

headline: Senior Client Services Representative
pros: They have great benefits: medical, 401k and retirement plan, plus bonuses. They have some great local leadership. Voluntary overtime is nearly always available.
cons: There was not a clear 'path' to promotions. Training used to be well rounded. Now the training is very specific so the representatives do not get to see the whole picture.

headline: Client service representative (operations)
pros: Benefits and internship opportunities are great.
cons: Management, pay, and the politics.

headline: Sr. Client service rep
pros: Great company with great benefits.
cons: It's not as easy to grow professionally as one might like.

headline: lack of growth
pros: Job stability, and great benefits.  The retirement plan is great.
cons: Lack of growth and upward mobility; it takes too many years to progress

headline: Senior Operations Manager
pros: The benefits, pay and work/life balance are great.  They are very careful who they hire, so the people are smart and nice.
cons: Shrinking service model.  Decisions often take a long time to be made.  Collaborative decision-making process can be frustrating at times.

headline: Career stagnation
pros: Pay and benefits are very competitive
cons: Very little opportunity to advance.  Get experience somewhere else and join the organization at the most senior level possible.

headline: Excellent
pros: Great place to work! The training is quite extensive and fellow employees are very friendly. Benefits are top notch.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Good company
pros: The company had great benefits and an awesome retirement.  You can't find many companies who offer something comparable.  Bonuses are nice!
cons: Turned into a call center environment.  People aren't trained like they were 10 years ago, they aren't able to help the customers.

headline: Salary
pros: Great company environment, great people
cons: No down sides. A great job.

headline: Administrative Coordinator
pros: beautiful offices, light work load, great team, fantastic benefits including two annual bonuses, job security
cons: all the pitfalls of a big company: impersonal management, disconnected policies, powerless lower level employees

headline: Amazing
pros: The benefits are great! The pay is great! My colleagues are great! The campus here in Indianapolis is gorge!!!! The cafeteria onsite is delicious. They really know how to treat their employees and I can sayvthisbis the best company I've ever worked for. No lie! Seriously, I'm very impressed how organized this company is. The training has been the most strategic and well organized I've ever witnessed in life. Everything you will need to know about your position they will teach you. They give you the proper resources and it's just been absolutey wonderful. They also give you so many opportunities to grow and move up in the company.
cons: I honestly can not think of a combat the moment. I've had such a positive experience with capital.

headline: Be Careful
pros:
Great benefits 
Very welcoming company
cons: There are a lot of things that pop up on you. Be very sure to read everything in the offer letter.

headline: Need to improve
author_position: Was A Technical Specialist Before CG
pros: Other than Google, and Amazon that I know of will try to exceed the total compensation (MRP and bonuses, salary and benefits) that Capital Group offers.  The base salary is average, and the annual rise is low compare to my last employer.   New management do listen, that is a plus.
cons:
Good folks from Infosys tends to have higher turnovers in a year.  So, it is a constant knowledge transfer from associates to Infosys new replacement.  At the same time, experienced associates in our group is getting thinner from transfers and resignation.
Process and bureaucracy is killing agility.

headline: Great Benefits but worst place to grow in career
pros: Good Salary, Above Industry Benefits, Good People, Great Campus and Facilities
cons: Arrogant HR, no growth for employees - more show than actual action, very slow organization, they try to brain wash you with capital dominance, lately lot of very good people have left. Even if they know something is wrong with a person they are very slow to act.

headline: nice.
pros: Fun place to work, friendly people
cons: no really any cons, really good place

headline: Takes dedication
pros: Uncapped earning potential if you have the drive.
cons: Constantly changing management and employees.

headline: Client services rep
pros: Good vacation hours as well as sick time. You don't have to go to management to ask for a day off you just enter it and if hours are available you get the day off. Full time. Decent pay. I get 36k a year pre tax of course. Good retirement plan. Nice co workers. Over time is available to be worked sometimes.
cons: 9 hour days do to 1 hour lunch. Only one shift available. Too many managers. Can be a stepford wives type of environment sometimes where everyone is all super nice and possibly fake(at least their true colors never show... If they do exist). It's long boring and mind numbing... I take call after call each day non stop and it's crushing my soul. No creativity no nothing... Just processing transactions for clients and answering some rather mundane questions for them. I HATE IT.

headline: Sr. Graphic Designer
pros: Nice people, great work environment, low stress.
cons: Many layers of management, work is not very creative. Little to no room for growth.

headline: Work-Life Balance
pros: Great work / life balance, vacation
cons: firm hierarchy, don't reward for furthering education

headline: Great Company
pros: Great pay, great benefits, work life balance and independence. The company has great values and it shows.
cons: Things take longer to get done due to process. Can be meeting heavy

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Great benefits, structured and thorough initial training, opportunity for additional training, team atmosphere so you have lots of support when needed, and management tries to show appreciation for associate contribution to company success. A lot is expected of you each day, but you are well compensated for your hard mental work. Emphasis in call center is on quality much more than on quantity.
cons: The team atmosphere with a good or fair team leader can make the job great, but the team atmosphere with a bad team leader can make going to work each day something to dread.

headline: Sr Customer Service Rep
pros: Great benefits, don't have to sell or be licensed
cons: Micro-managed and boring. Since Lovelace passed away the new management has driven the company down. They don't care about the workers any more.

headline: Overall a Great Company to Work For
pros: American Funds has great benefits, stellar coworkers, on-site cafeteria and gym, and lots of fun activities throughout the year.
cons: Being on the phone all day (taking inbound calls) is extremely taxing and can be hard to deal with day after day.

headline: Client Services Representative
pros: Excellent training program makes sure you are prepared to handle any situation. Great support from other associates, managers, and senior managers. Excellent benefits.
cons: Lateral movement. When given more responsibility, there is no pay increase, rather it looks for your review.

headline: Client Services Team Manager
pros: Retirement plan-MRP-15% of all pay invested on your behalf (you pick investments). Vested at 6 years!
cons: Long hours, can be a favoritism game

headline: Typical Corporate Experience
pros:
Good bonus (roughly 15% a year performance bonus - varies based on performance)
15% contributed to master retirement account
consistent June bonus based on profitability of company
cons: Typical corporate environment with lots of managers, and very little individuality

headline: Senior Quality Engineer
pros: High caliber employees, principles/values driven, thoughtful decision makers, excellent pay and benefits - especially for tenured associates, and lots of opportunities.
cons: Lots of contractors (including sizable offshore presence), high turnover rate with contractors, takes too long to make decisions, collaboration is good but it is excessive, and trying to do too much with too few associates.

headline: Ok.
pros: Good people, great profit sharing, vacay, laid back people, good team environment that fosters growth for some. Must look the part to be an external.
cons: Constant changes, micro managing, no stability in bonus structure, middle managers don't give honest info to employees, need more money

headline: senior customer service specialist
pros: Great benefits, great retirement plan, fantastic physical environment, good compensation
cons: Little room for growth, middle management does not have an effective accountability process which leads to inconsistent management and favoritism.

headline: Humility and Respect
pros: Core values are actually lived and evident.  Great opportunities to expand your skill set if you seek out opportunities.
cons: Limited upward mobility as attrition is low.  Most of the company could me more agile in responding to market place changes.

headline: financial processing clerk
pros: It was ok pay and a nice facility
cons: Working there felt like I was a robot, they tell us where to park when to take lunch how often we can get up from our seat to wake ourselves up mind you we sit in front of computers all day and can barely talk. They talked to us like we were dumb and I didn't like it. They give you feedback for everything and they don't want you to make any mistakes or you will get terminated from the assignment which I think is ridiculous. Not my type of job

headline: CSR
pros: This company is great! You make your own way, and performance spof ask for itself. Do you want opportunities? Strong work ethic and comprehension is a necessity.  This is an incredibly detailed industry.  Learn it, or get out! People's' futures, people investments are at stake and if the employees don't take the time, effort, or care, those who rely upon American Funds suffer.  It is imperative to be receptive to feedback. One must be willing to grow with the company.  There is a reason Capital group has been in existence since the GREAT DEPRESSION, and even more reason why the Anerican Funds family has withstood the test of time in an ever-changing, ever-volatile industry.  And it still maintains rank among the top investment providers and managers IN THE WORLD!
cons: Once the Company is invested in an individual, they work too hard to maintain relationships, rather than seeing people's true colors and cutting ties.  This mentality tends to drag down the morale and level of customer service expected from AFS.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great benefits, they are good to their employees
cons: Closing Scottsdale office in June

headline: Client Services Specialist
pros: Great Company overall. Upper end of pay compared to other similar companies. Good benefits and in particular the retirement plan.
cons: Core Values stated by the company are generally followed, particularly at the upper levels of management, but not as much as it filters through the layers of management down into the service centers. Too much emphasis on having to be a self-promoter of ones accomplishment as opposed to management identifying your contributions.

headline: Team Manager
pros: Great people, benefits and Retirement plan.  Lots of resources for self development.
cons: AZ office closing after 10 yrs of positive contribution.

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros: Engaged Employer, Great benefits, great company culture
cons: Call Center, you are on phones 80-90% of the day.

headline: administrative assistant
pros: nice, friendly co-workers, no micromanagement
cons: very strict on time OOO (ie- lunch), chained to your desk

headline: Excellent benefits package, Good overall experience.
pros: CG does have an excellent benefits package, Good pay, nice office facilities, parking garage (nice in the San Antonio summer), and I really enjoyed the working relationship with most of the people there.
cons: Experiencing growing pains (medium becoming large company), business infrastructure under constant development, frequent changes to everyday processes. And it's a privately held company behaving like a public one with too much emphasis on the bottom line. (My employment was discontinued along with 40 other people so that upper management could reach a goal presented to the board, regardless of the fact that we had plenty of work to do and the company was under no financial distress)

headline: Very corporate
pros: Core values influence most employees' interactions, physical environment, privately held.
cons: Going through constant change that is not well managed due to lack of experience by leadership.

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: Great Benefits and wonderful culture
cons: Closing AZ Office in June 2015

headline: System Support Representative
pros: diverse tasks, multiple systems to learn, on the job training
cons: no room to move, no flexibility on schedule, low morale

headline: Amazing company, culture and people
pros: Capital Group is a premiere employer that cares about its clients and its associates. Company core values are taken seriously and can be felt throughout all levels of the organization. There are many opportunities to grow professionally if one is looking to advance their career.
cons: The decision-making process can be quite lengthy.

headline: American Funds
pros: Great benefits and great people
cons: Scottsdale office is closing soon

headline: Slow in change and progression of innovative ideas, however loyal to the worker.
pros: Campus is amazing, people are friendly, culture is great.
cons: Slow in innovation and deployment.

headline: Good overall and great benefits
pros: Benefits are terrific.  People are smart and you'll learn a great deal.  You'll also be stretched and you'll work very hard.
cons: Decisions take too long. Very challenging to advance from within.

headline: American Funds is a great company to start and build experience while you discover what it is you want to do.
pros: Great benefit package . Master retirement plan, bonuses, insurance, time away are all above other companies
cons: Micro managing, no work life balance, although they say they are a family company you Wil see quickly that is not the case

headline: Good place to work- no jerks.
pros: Kind people in all roles at Capital.
cons: Hard to change anything in the company.

headline: Great company, many management disconnects and organizational alignment issues complex in scope.
pros: Everyone friendly and professional. Pleasurable work environment.
cons: Poor alignment creates challenging means to address change

headline: Great place to work
pros: The company really takes care of you and the best benefits in the business
cons: Just Closing the Scottsdale office

headline: GREAT first time Job but not a career
pros:
National company with extensive training and education. 
AMAZING Benefits
Great working environment and amazing people
cons:
Required overtime each week
Limited advancement potential
Inconsistent enforcement of policy

headline: Good salary/benefits package; conformist, soul-sucking, hidebound atmosphere
pros: Good salary and benefits. Good work/life balance.
cons:
As other reviewers have said: "Stepford-like." Everyone is an automaton, even zombie-like. If you have a different opinion than someone in authority, you will be viewed as disagreeable. Everyone is superficially nice, but people don't accept different opinions. The company is really hidebound. Also, depending on your position, you could be chained to your desk. You're not treated like an adult.

There are impenetrable layers of authority and bureaucracy. Nothing gets done. Ever. It's frustrating. Everyone is a project manager, so projects never get completed. You spend half your life in pointless meetings so people can hear themselves talk.

If you're in asset management, and you actually manage money for the firm, I imagine it could be a great gig. If you do any of the ancillary tasks associated with asset management, it's a disaster.

headline: Great at first, sad ending...
pros: Amazing benefits, including excellent health care, 2 cash bonuses per year, a flexible 4x10 schedule, extremely generous yearly contribution to a retirement account (15%!). Free lunches or treats to help motivate or thank employees for hard work. The company tends to hire really good people, and almost everyone is professional and friendly.
cons: Poor decisions by management, allowed for 3+ years of MANDATORY overtime every single week without hiring. Several employees left by year 2. I lasted until year 3 and could take no more of the totally lost "worklife/balance". I left an exhausted and grumpy person, thankfully able to take some time off and be my cheery self again. Did not particularly enjoy some of the processing, can be a real downer processing death claims or trying to correct giant mistakes and working with demanding clients. Getting vacation time became extremely difficult in last few years, again due to refusal of management to hire, and understaffed department. Getting time off at Christmas or New Years was akin to winning the lottery. Moving up/promotions can be a very slow process.

headline: Good lifetime gig
pros:
Respectful colleagues
15% "pension" contribution
Great campus in Irvine
cons:
Slow to no promotions
Sometimes 24 hours On  Calls

headline: decent place to work
pros: benefits best ive ever encountered
cons: closed the pho site, making my job vanish

headline: Capital Group had an excellent training program and a good management structure
pros: The training was very in depth and ongoing. Management was very involved and strived to maintain a work-life balance. The benefits were good with and had additional perks like gym membership.
cons: The work was tedious and repetitive. The pay was fairly low.

headline: Great compensation and benefits, but company has lost its way recently. Listening to too many outside influencers.
pros: compensation, benefits, bonuses, time-off policies
cons: lack of promotions, unfocused strategy

headline: Awesome company, benefits and culture.
pros: Great benefits, competitive pay, work-life balance, emphasis on employee well-being.
cons: Not a lot of promotion opportunities.

headline: good benefits, low promotion rate
pros: benefits, cafe, quality of employees
cons: old software, slow to change

headline: Check your personality at the door
pros: Great salary and compensation package.
cons: Very stepford-like. Check your personality at the door when you accept the job offer. No room for growth unless you work in IRV or LAO. Takes way too long to make and implement decisions. Don't think too out of the box or disagree with key people or you will be labeled disagreeable and hard to work with.

headline: Great place to be
pros: When I had only been on the job for 1 week I had a very unforeseen family emergency. They treated me as if I were a multi-year tenured associate.  I am grateful for my 10 years with American Funds
cons: Would like more in-service training.

headline: Great job straight out of college.
pros: 401k match & health benefits
cons: You are disposable and upper management is not open to new ideas.

headline: Great benefits, steady pay, slow to adapt
pros: The benefits are top notch, from the Health, 401k and work life balance to NAV for American Funds purchases.
cons: Technology is archaic and very slow to adapt/improve. Decision making is done at a snails pace. Limit opportunities in certain departments/locations.

headline: Great company that takes great care of their employees.
pros: Great people, positive work environment, good management, great pay and incredible retirement package. Lately had been a lot of technology changes which is fun to learn.
cons: There are a lot of great employees on the phones that just haven't had the opportunity to move up into bigger roles.

headline: This is the place to be if you wanted a stable, middling, zero advancement career.
pros: People around generally are very collegial, although the culture has morphed in recent years with the addition of  a few  younger associates that are adept at managing upwards but disdainful to support staff, only deigning to talk to you when they need your help.  Nonetheless, if you like to work with smart people, this is a great place to learn. If you like a stable job with no growth but perpetually good healthcare benefits, this is the firm for you.
cons: It is very old school, and management/culture has not been effectual in improving career development of employees at all. There is a stigma associated with entering the firm at a junior level, and how you progress tends to be determined by which program you came in, not by aptitude. Internal candidates that have been earmarked for promotion tend to wait around for years while the firm goes out on a limb for outsiders. They have enacted some superficial steps for improvement, but an ingrained culture that is against promoting from within is hard to change. This is relevant only to the investment group. The firm is generally more helpful in career development if you are in any other departments.

headline: Was once a great company to work for.
pros: Compensation is very competitive.  Good location..
cons: People are dispensable; no longer most important asset.

headline: Typical Corporate Nightmare.. Make sure you get your TPS reports turned in.
pros: There aren't really any pros to list about this job except that you get a consistent paycheck, which is VERY low.
cons: Micromanagement, Micromanagement, and Micromanagement.  You will be a bottom of the barrel Call center, sweat shop slave for near minimum wage.. and low wage for a VERY stressfull, intricate job.

headline: It use to be a world class company and now is just one of the worst places to work
pros: Good benefits, nice cafeteria and gym
cons: They constantly changing the process, no opportunities to growth, you don't now for how long you are going to be working for the company, they are in the process of eliminating all positions  and give to overseas company like INFOSYS from India

headline: Great company, both pay and benefits were top notch
pros: culture, interesting assignments, compensation, company paid master retirement program
cons: gaining agreement among users who had  diverse objectives

headline: Many "engagement" surveys, tepid action
pros: Benefits and pay are fantastic. Probably the primary reason why people stay. The facilities are very pleasant (but no gym). If you are in the trenches like most, the people you work with are cordial and helpful
cons: Seems like it is taking senior management a lot of time (years) to respond to employee engagement surveys which repeatedly state the lack of growth and career opportunities. The fact is, as automation takes over and the business is more efficient there will be a need for less people. The people sitting behind the glass offices are entrenched. They are in career preservation mode. The lack of action speaks more than words.  You can introduce a bunch of new tools that capture development plans, but most of the time year after year, even if you meet or go above your performance objectives it is hard to get recognized.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: Lot of scope to grow with the company.
cons: Bad Administration and Lot of layoffs

headline: It's alright in here
pros: Open communication . Really good company to work for. However if you have aspirations to climb a ladder, look elsewhere.
cons: There is no ladder to climb. Just be content with your job title. You will get opportunities to improve your skills, but no recognition for a job well done or don't expect a promotion until you sit on your title for several years.

headline: Never looking back
pros: The benefits and people were very nice.
cons: It became a call center, the Team Managers were weak and always trying to prove their worth. Many people that would have made great supervisors would never get a chance and others you would have no clue how they got into the position. Also Team Managers were confrontational and no matter how well you did do something there was always feedback.

headline: So far so good.
pros: Great training, good schedules, adheres to holidays that correspond with the NYSE
cons: Nothing so far. Still new.

headline: Team Manager
pros: Benefits are great.  Pay is good.  Been there 10 years and get five weeks vacation.  Retirement without any matching is 15%.  Bonus week of vacation for every five years of employment.
cons: Went from a service center to more of a call center.  A lot of temporary workers with 18 months max contract are employed.  The quality suffers some.

headline: Have no ambition to grow. Salary rise is very marginal. Too many managers
pros: Nice work place with cafe
cons: Almost no growth. Minimum promotions. Very manager oriented company - if your manager does not like you then find another job. Most managers have dated technical knowledge but will pretend they understand a lot

headline: A good start, some good benefits but not worth it
pros: Work-life balance is great, pretty generous on the vacation time in comparison to other places. Campus is quite nice. They have other small little perks like movie tickets for sale at the cafe, being able to ship out packages, and subsidized monthly train passes. Most of the people they hire are friendly and it's not too hard to develop some good friendships here.
cons: Coming in I thought this would be a place where I could develop a long term career. The people were friendly, there seemed to be a large support system, and the campus was beautiful. During the tours they gave us, staff would always point out the best things (great cafe food, big open campus, free coffee, open door policy for managers, etc). After some time though the facade starts to fade away and you start seeing what is really going on. I have gotten a sense from some of the older workers that the company used to be better but the financial crash of 2008 really changed things. Mandatory overtime can run up to 2 hours a day which can really drain you throughout the course of a week. Time off during the year end holidays is very hard to get. Upward mobility is very slow, very few openings for managerial positions. More lateral than upward movement. Management tries to make things seem nicer than they are, my favorite being calling overtime "additional time." Company is very very slow to adapt to change both with external and internal policies. Training can feel long and overdrawn. I really wish I could recommend this company because at first it sounds amazing. At the end of the day though, I am not happy and I can very much tell there are several other associates who are not happy.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great benefits, great pay, nice people to work with.
cons: Lots of overtime, hard to advance

headline: Perfect out of college experience.
pros: Most of the people I encountered where extremely enjoyable and friendly. The company offers great incentives.
cons: Mobility can be limited.

headline: If you have any ambition in life look elsewhere.
pros: The pay is ok and the coffee machines are nice.
cons: If you are a 40 something who went to a cal-state school with no ambition in life and has never lived outside of Orange County, this place is a sweet deal. If however you have a brain and are ambitious this place will be mind numbing and soul draining. Lots of people have been here for 15-20 years...in the same position and on the same team. That should tell you something. If you went to a ranked school and are used to collaborative environments do not look here, you will be judged by your age and there is no people management or mentorship, your career will go nowhere and you will learn nothing new. I would never recommend this place to anyone I know.

headline: The worst company I have ever worked for...
pros: In house cafeteria, pay well as a contractor.
cons: Company does not have any values. Manager like to hire they own people (Indian) Discrimination. They differentiate between contractor and fulltime employee, and will look down on you. I would not recommend anyone coming here.

headline: Some good and bad but overall, buyer beware.
pros: Retirement and health ins is top notch. Comp was reasonable but they tell management when they are hired that they know they pay at a minimum 25% less than the industry, so just beware.  Good amount of time-off.  If you work in the sites your average work week will be 40-45 hours, so good work-life balance.  Nice facilities.  If you have a great manager who believes in fighting for their people (which is rare) follow them wherever they go.
cons:
Senior management hires more managemnt to insulate themselves.
Layers upon layers.
If you move up the ladder from within pay may be 25- 30 percent less than those that are hired from outside the company.  You will see a lot of people able to squeak by and get promoted while not doing much.  Micro management.  If you are hard working you will always have a target on your back.  You will see that people at the top hire their buddies to insulate themselves.  Good ole boy system is alive and well.  Can be very difficult to get ahead and be treated with respect if you are a female.  Bonuses are not necessarily based on merit.  They talk about their "open door policy," but don't do that.  Be very careful about what you voice and how.  Creativity is not fostered nor encouraged.  Environment fosters apathy.  Many people with ill intentions get promoted.

headline: Graphic Production Artist
pros: Good company takes care of it's employees, promotes continued learning, and advancement from within. All associates are nice, and easy to work with.
cons: Separation between contract associates, and regular associates.

headline: Long-term employee, who has seen many changes within the organization.  Some positive and some challenging.
pros: The company generally strives to maintain high levels of employee satisfaction with competitive salaries, amazing benefits and a focus on career growth and development.  The overall culture is respectful and supportive.  The work is very challenging and interesting, which can mostly be attributed to the ongoing evolution of the financial industry.
cons: There have been many recent changes in leadership within the organization.  Many associates have had several managers within a short time-frame, making it challenging to build strong working relationships.  We've also added quite a few more layers of management adding to the number of stakeholders who are part of the decision making process.  More opinions have been leading to longer decision making and political jockeying.

headline: Integrity and Fairness
pros: This is a place where people have strong values and great integrity. I work here because I know I will never have to apologize for what my employer does - I can't say this about many other financial services companies. There is a thorough review process that is fair and enables flexible career paths.
cons: Traffic in Los Angeles can be a real drag!

headline: Kit maker
pros: Leaving work at your assigned time.
cons: Working with very insecure, jealous, mentally challenged females.

headline: Experience at Capital
pros: Collaborative environment where an individual can thrive
cons: The organization is growing its digital prescence to compete

headline: Very good company
pros: So many opportunities, great culture and great leadership
cons: Need better office facility and cafe menu

headline: Good people overall, good culture, great pay. Lack of upward mobility, painful period of restructuring
pros:
Very little political back-stabbing.
Great compensation compared to its competitors
Great learning tools available
Good work-life balance
Relaxed environment
cons:
Decision-making is concentrated at the top

Very little upward mobility--IT is bringing outside folks, mostly from Accenture as managers. Since most of the new managers have not gone through a full life-cycle with support, it leads to unrealistic expectations. Further, most of the accenture folks come with an attitude built-in: they are arrogant to a 't' and have no problem showing it. It takes them two years to mellow and get out of that mode. 

Don't expect "personal growth." Not there, won't be there for at least the next 5 years.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Good work life balance
Great salary
cons: Career progression slow especially if you are in enabling functions

headline: Fantastic Firm
pros: As a private company, Capital Group can invest in it's employees and business for the long-term and it shows.  In particular, the firm has a clear, consistent, long-term strategy.  As a result, the environment is very collegial and supportive.  Everyone works hard, but enjoys it.  The interview process is long and arduous, but it results in a group of great colleagues.
cons: I don't have any cons.

headline: It's a call center
pros: Amazing benefits and comfortable work environment
cons: Overtime and lack of room for growth when in the call center

headline: Working at CG
pros: Medical benefits, vacation, office amentities are top notch
cons: Lack of career mobility, over managed

headline: Great office space but little career opportunity
pros: Great compensation, Excellent office space
cons: Company has a disjointed operating style, Little career development and opportunity

headline: Easy job promoted to manager after 10 years, loving it
pros:
Time off is great, work life balance.
Can leave early
Nice place to eat, plenty of budget for the department.  
Great Senior Manager and director makes things go smooth
cons:
Outsourcing is good for the bottom line.
I'd like to have had a chance to be considered for certain duties before its outsourced.

headline: Capital group is a strong company to establish a long term employment relationship with.
pros: Benefits with regard to retirement are easily some of the best offerings around.
cons: Opportunities for advancement may be currently limiting.

headline: Great Benefits but unplanned Time off is tough
pros:
The company benefits: retirement plan, investment in their funds, medical, dental, disability are hard to beat. I've worked for several employers and have yet to find a company that matches the benefits offered by the Capital Group at an affordable cost.

The managers are good about coaching employees on how to share ideas & their opinions in a positive, respectful manner. This has been a huge benefit for me both professionally and personally.
cons: Time off around holidays is almost impossible to get. For non-holiday time off, you have to notify the company at least 3 months in advance or you will most likely not be approved. While Capital offers to cover the cost of business-related degrees, there is not a benefit to earning one.

headline: A company in transition.
pros: The company is very good at what they do and have a lot of excellent people working to accomplish their goals.  Benefits are great and the work environment is second to none.
cons: The company is in the midst of some growing pains with regards to culture and identity.  A lot of process and procedure is being dropped on the departments without much thought of affecting productivity.  So most things now taken longer than they should to get to resolution.

headline: Sr.Operator
pros: Very collaborative Environment, Minimum 3 week time off, Good work-life balance.
cons: Growth Potenial is very less to become manager or Sr.Manager.

headline: So much potential...used to be a great place to work now it's semi-good...
pros: OK place to work, nice environment, most employees are professional. The compensation and benefits are also good.
cons: Very difficult to advance to a management position. Some middle managers over work their high performing associates to the point of having them do their job and not being recognized for it or properly compensated. It is extremely competitive. After working there for almost 9 years as an excellent associate, I should have been promoted to a hirer position. It's very disappointing and frustrating, I am now currently looking to work with a different employer, I feel burned out....

headline: Started bumpy but great experience
pros: After change in senior leadership, customer service/marketing department promoted teamwork, developing associates, and manager development.
cons: Higher as supervisor from outside co. and while went through product/technical training, no training on "how things worked, the culture".  Should have had mentor/peer explain ins and outs.

headline: Used to be a great company to work for
pros: Fair compensation, time off and great co-workers
cons: The company culture used to be great. It was a very collaborate and great working environment but the company has taken a turn for the worst in the last couple of years since the retirement of several high ranking partners left. It's now very competitive and people are out to make themselves look good.  Managers are forced by higher senior managers to enforce and execute this new cut-throat culture.

headline: Capital Group
pros: Great retirement benefits. Lots of time off.
cons: Limited upward mobility opportunity. Pay is not competitive.

headline: Top-notch, cream of the crop employer!
pros: Everything they do, they do very well. There is no half-stepping with this company! The health insurance and other benefits are phenomenal. I've noticed that the ones with negative things to say seem to be be folks who've had very little time in the job market or they've been with the company entirely too long and have forgotten what a good company it is!
cons: They are very detail oriented - the demands of the industry require it.

headline: Solid company to work for.
pros: Compensation and benefits are great.  Work environment is outstanding.  People are professional and caring.
cons: There are way too many contractors in some departments.  If they don't get hired on too much time is spent training every 12-18 months.

headline: Conservative company, limited opportunities to move upward.
pros: People really stick to the core values of the firm. Every discussion revolves around ensuring that shareholders are served well. The integrity of CG associates is excellent, and there is always an effort to ensure that project leaders engage across functions to make the best decisions possible. The company has been around for 80 years, and has earned its reputation as an upstanding long-term investment firm.
cons: Conservatism and team-focused efforts have a dark side: they keep folks from getting things done. I found management often unable to make a decision out of fear that they had somehow not gotten buy-in from every potential party. The 80/20 rule doesn't exist there--you have to run decisions and potential actions by every single person who might be affected. Risk tolerance is zero, which hampers the ability to move quickly.

headline: Good, but no longer GREAT
pros: You have the opportunity to interact and collaborate with some very intelligent and professional people--some would even say there's too much collaboration. I've made some great, what I know will be life long friends working there. Pay is more than fair, especially once bonuses are factored in and the benefits are in the upper quartile of all companies. There are plentiful opportunities to get involved with non-profits as well as volunteer opportunities in the community. Work-life balance is a consideration, at least in my department.
cons: When I first started working here, there were very few layers of management so you always felt like you had a voice and could make a difference by influencing a decision maker. Nowadays, senior managers manage senior managers and there are way more layers of bureaucracy than ever before. Upper management positions constantly seem to be filled with outsiders and corporate values seem to have eroded over time. A defined career path is one of the most desired items by employees but HR has done a poor job communicating their plan to offer one.

headline: Best job I've ever had
pros: The associates here are extremely intelligent, capable, and professional. In every sense of the word. The recruitment process is long and dire to make sure the people who come through the door full-time deserve to be here.
cons: Bigger, more bureaucratic company than the usual fund. Pays less than other alternatives (PE/Hedge Fund) but the work-life balance is fantastic.

headline: great experience
pros: work-life balance, good perks given hours of work,
cons: promotions, good for people who aim to build family

headline: Great company to work for if you have no ambition and don't mind bad management.
pros: Competitive salary and benefits. Associates are generally nice and respectful.
cons: Leadership is pretty weak. Some team managers like to play favorites and will only make accommodations for them. Senior team managers are gone for the majority of the day. Mandatory overtime puts a strain on work-life balance and there is no room for advancement.

headline: Great company!
pros: Great benefits, caring culture, and very professional.  There is true work-life balance here for being on the buyside.  The ability to focus on investing is truly a treasure.
cons: Since the company is so large it can take a little while to get up to speed on all the benefits and procedures.

headline: Long time for decisions to be made
pros: Great compensation with two yearly bonuses and above normal pay for area. Perks include retirement plan and fee-free access to company services.
cons: IT Leadership is focused on outsourcing jobs. You train your replacements from a third party. IT leadership takes forever to make a decision and the engineering group has more power and influence  over IT direction because their director has sold himself as a "technology guy" simply because he brought an iPad to work 4 years ago. The company likes to pride itself on its history to the world but inside its a mommy dearest scenario.

headline: Best company to work for
pros: Has great benefits and corporate culture
cons: Managers don't pay attention to employee growth

headline: A good place to work if you are established in your career. Benefits and scope of work can be really great!
pros: Nice people, retirement benefit, great physical environment, strong ethics.
cons: In some departments, career growth is stagnant, despite attempts to make it appear differently (trainings and education assistance).

headline: Awesome work culture
pros: work with friendly environment
cons: The work pressure is lesser as compared to other companies with job security

headline: Company went from great to good
pros:
- Tenure based benefits  - vacation, bonuses, generous retirement plan
- Onsite activities such as carnivals, BINGO nights and BBQs
- Community service days
- Campus is beautiful, can't beat the surroundings
- Bonds formed with co-workers
cons:
- Senior leadership
- Shift in top-down culture 
- Lack of innovation
- Employees feel like they can't voice their opinion when it's different than those who are in leadership
- Lack of opportunities at senior levels - those who don't belong in senior levels aren't being effectively performanced managed

headline: Capital Group
pros: Everyone is very friendly and willing to help. There's a great work-life balance because it's rare for people to take work home.
cons: It's hard to move up and get promotions because someone has to either transfer to another department or quit for a managerial spot to be open.

headline: Great pay, benefits - no opportunities for advancement in Texas
pros:
competitive pay and benefits, bonuses still. biggest pro.
decent culture though not what they "sell" really
nice work environment
relaxed dress code -denim & biz casual
company solid financially
cons:
Career opps for IT primarily in Irvine, CA.  
Leadership mostly there and unable or unwilling to consider diverse multi-site locations for positions & teams very often if ever any more even though this is a global company with big investment in real estate and IT infrastructure in Texas.  Does everyone really have to sit beside each other today? With our IT capabilities, work from home, telepresence, etc. this seems antiquated.  Trust issues? cheaper in Texas so cost is unlikely.
Impossible to get ahead.  Promotions for your direct reports (we are talking title changes only here) require approval from the Pope and the President practically.  They probably think we just don't want to promote them.  If they only knew! 
No real openings in Texas to move around much in management or otherwise so promoting that way is hard too.  Move to CA? Get ready to pay state tax with your pay bump.  No thanks.  Basically will not be a seriously competitive IT employer in SA for much longer at this rate.  Will have too small of a presence with not enough interesting job offerings.

headline: Terrible place to work
pros: Cafeteria with chefs on hand
cons: Management fired me for being on the internet too much and I worked in the IT department! Are you serious? Joke!

headline: Great work atmosphere for the first  several years until upper management changed the entire day-to-day work structure.
pros: They offer fantastic benefits when it comes to medical, dental, vision insurance; along with a 401k and contribution to a Master Retirement Plan.  The Irvine campus is quite beautiful as well.
cons: Major micro-management.  Managers seem to want you to be able to account for every minute you are not signed in at your desk.   Capital Group used to focus on providing quality customer service, but their associate morale has worsened tremendously ever since they changed their American Funds' Shareholder Services department to a call center type atmosphere.

headline: Started off great...ended as a sweat shop
pros: Great benefits- Great people to work with - Pretty decent pay- 2 bonuses a year
cons: No work/life balance- no room to move up- tons of required overtime

headline: Foot soldiers are abused by out of touch power hungry Middle Managers
pros: Retirement Account, Some of the Top Managers have morals.
cons: Middle Managers are out of touch, can't do the work, have zero empathy for the Foot Soldiers, abuse them, are at home with their families while the Foot Soldier has to work overtime and weekends to keep up.

headline: unique large company culture, extreme collaboration, solid benefit and stability but outdated business plan
pros:
1.  Great work life balance
2.  Good salary and benefit
3.  Each employee opinion count, not sure if this is pros or cons.
cons:
1.  A few steps behind current market leader
2.  Efficiency between business and IT relationship is highly questionable.  Some departments are better then other.
3.  Being large company, heavy politic involve in getting anything done, seems extremely inefficient
4.  Super top heavy

headline: American Funds Shareholder Services
pros: Benefits, fair compensation, excellent medical/dental/vision, fair paid time off
cons: Flat organization, no room to grow

headline: Great people and work environment, but very difficult to get ahead
pros: Great work environment. Still some life work balance left. Really great people to work with who are very smart and respectful to each other.
cons: This company has very talented people who join the firm as very motivated and wanting to make a difference, but quickly learn that decisions take forever, and that collaboration is so excessive that it's actually anti-beneficial.  Getting ahead in your career is the biggest challenge. Most Sr. positions are filled with external hires from consultancies.

headline: Great Company
pros: I loved the atmosphere, everyone was always in a positive mood and happy to be at work. It was easy to work as a team and speak with supervisors about any issues or questions.
cons: While I worked at Capital Group I did not have any cons. Truly, each day was a great experience.

headline: Still a great company although slipping a bit
pros: Very respectful professional environment; very democratic for a financial firm. Excellent salary and benefits. Strong senior management.
cons: Slow career progression; recent personnel/structural changes are concerning. Less focus on the investor than in the past.

headline: worst 6 months of my life
pros: Pay and benefits are very good. The San Antonio Campus is beautiful with onsite Café, Gym, little Pocket Parks, Underground Parking.
cons: Co-Workers that do not know you, don't work with you, may never have spoken to you feel the need to, and are allowed to give "feedback" to your Manager about silly things like what you appear to feel like.

headline: Low risk job
pros: Everyone has a job for life, ability to hire as many people as you want, only have to work a few hours a day, everything is driven by tenure of your time here so you just have to be willing to stay for 20 years then people will listen to you.  Everything can always wait another year or two so never much pressure to do anything better or quicker or use a cheaper solution, and no need to answer your phone or deal with annoying people as with other companies where quick results are expected.  Provides for a great lifestyle!
cons: Not much merit focus but it depends upon what you want

headline: Institutional Client Marketing and Service
pros: Solid, stable company with strong leadership. But not as good as it was before.
cons: No longer an employee focused firm.  Lack of upward mobility.

headline: Great place to work.  The IT organization continuew to evolve to better meet the businesses needs.
pros:
Competitive pay
Great Benefits
Great Retirement Plan
Good Work Life Balance
Privately held with long term focus
Always looking for innovative ways to improve IT service delivery.  New ideas are always welcome and encouraged.
cons: The long term focus can mean that implementing ideas can take an extended amount of time as you build support for your idea as you collaborate with other teams and stake holders.

headline: Great benefits, check your ambition at the door
pros: Company sponsored retirement plan that contributes 15%; generous vacation, education benefits. Two annual bonuses, NAV purchases on American Funds mutual funds
cons:
Painfully slow career development - in some instances, 10+ years before being placed in a supervisory position. Went on a hiring freeze from 2008-2011, but now that business has picked up since the Financial Crisis, mgmt is scrambling to keep up with hiring needs. 

Historically deliberate in decision making, the organization has been making technological and operational "enhancements" at an increased pace over the last several years. Many of these updates have resulted in system interruptions and other issues that should have been caught in testing.

headline: To be or not to be
pros: The health and MRP benefits are good
cons:
To be 'in the inner circle' or to 'be out'. One either has to 'fit in' with the higher ups regardless of your work ethic otherwise you are not 'a favorite' and do not get the special advantages. The culture of many years ago is gone. It is cut throat and who you know. Sadly, at the very top of the ladder, it is not seen how senior level managers treat people. Sr. managers do play favorites and ignore the fact that many people are lazy, come in late, take LONG lunches, disappear during the day, or even sleep at their desk hidden away in a corner. How can associates be online shopping all day instead of working? You tell a manger and it gets ignored because they do not want to deal with it and then they look at you as the bad guy for saying something. 
It's as though the great employees who have the highest work ethic and go above and beyond are not as valued as the 'so-so' employee who does enough to barely get by. Is it because the great ones raise the bar too high and makes the others look bad? Management needs to take a look around them and BE FAIR

headline: Not the typical corporate culture
pros: After a month at this company, I was amazed at how professional and respectful everyone was... a refreshing change after working at a Fortune 500 firm where managers had unrealistic expectations and bad tempers. My CG colleagues were intelligent, friendly, and fair-minded. No corporate backstabbing, very little gossip, and the most unpretentious, down-to-earth executive management I've ever met... the grandson of the company's founder had the same size office as the other managers! Great benefits, smart people, nice offices, good coffee.
cons: Our department chronically struggled with work-life balance, managing an ever-growing workload and often not adequately staffed. Career advancement is not a clear-cut path and growth opportunities were sometimes difficult to find.

headline: This company tries to take care of its people.
pros: Very good benefits,,, two type of bonuses.
cons: Limited opportunity if you are a contractor

headline: Low technology / unique benefits
pros: Depending on location, organic vegetable garden, all natural lighting in buildings, underground parking, healthy choices for breakfast and lunch, pre-made meals for dinner, and fitness facilities.
cons: technology is stuck in the late 80's and early 90's.  Management inept, progress takes forever to move forward, too much consolidation of positions, gender dominance works against other gender.
