If you are of a certain gender and want advancement it is a decent place.  If you are the other gender and have no desire to ever advance, then it is for you too.

headline: Smart place
pros:
Very smart people 
thoughtful approach 
insular culture
highly collaborative
cons:
2008 financial bust shook the place up and changed the culture a bit. 
Takes a lot of collaboration and consensus to get decisions made
slow place
lots of "lifers"

headline: Senior Accountant
pros: Great work life / balance.  Great benefits, especially retirement contribution. Very nice, intelligent employees that value teamwork and collaboration.  Very low turnover.
cons: Very difficult to advance in the organization.

headline: Pendantic Organization filled with insiders
pros: Great Pay Package (Golden Handcuffs), Benefits, Work Environment
cons: Culture of Collaboration - everyone has to agree to the solution or action - can hamper schedules. With great pay comes great expectations as to what your work schedule should be (daylight is not always in the schedule).  Lots of long time employees who insist on doing the same method that they have always done, only to wonder why it is so hard.

headline: A company in trouble
pros: Extravagant salaries, a luxurious campus, free coffee, and an inflated self-image.
cons: A deliberately blind leadership, a cutthroat culture, a business climate of planned obscurity.  No org charts are allowed, HR policies are largely unwritten in order to remain legally untouchable, and a planned "good old boy" system that ensures that if you're not "in," you're quickly out.  They are rapidly losing market share due to an outdated business model.  Because of their culture, rapid change is impossible.

headline: Great Learning Experience!
pros: I started off with a banking background and very little investment/mutual fund knowledge.  After attending the training, I feel I was very well versed in mutual funds and very prepared for the job.  My manager really seemed to want to help us gain more skills in various areas.  You have opportunities to try different positions, almost like internal internships.  Very good benefits.
cons: Not really many cons as it fit my needs.

headline: Wish I could say it wasn't a waste of time.
pros:
- Decent Pay
- Great Benefits
- Pretty Campus
- Solid Cafeteria
- Fairly stable company although they go through massive layoffs when the market tanks the same as everyone else.
cons:
- Company expects everybody to be as emotionally invested in it as though they are traders making big time dollars/dividends even if that employee is just a part of the process and not a revenue driver/reaping the benefits.

- Unnecessarily secretive regarding company direction and financial performance leading to uncertainty about ones future.

- Expectations upon associates that exceed compensation.

- Managerial philosophy that places a premium on "going the extra mile" throughout the company, but in practice it often leads to disenfranchisement when management essentially creates work for the sake of work and looking busy followed by dissenting employees being browbeaten.

-  Management claims to have desire to embrace innovation and new ideas. But in practice this is often discouraged with extreme prejudice. As though they know these things are important to the company's future while at the same time being extremely uncomfortable with the prospect of dealing with the associated ambiguity.

- Most of the work at the company resembles a glorified production line so it can be very difficult to get time off for a decent length vacation. 

-Promotes VERY difficult to come by.

-Back and middle office jobs/teams/departments are an absolutely brutal environments. I can't totally ding them for this though as it seems to be the case throughout the rest of the investment management industry as well.

- If you aren't part of the client facing component you are essentially a second class citizen.

headline: It used to be great
pros: Master Retirement Plan, nice office, some nice associates
cons: Since the new and "improved" processes have been in place, everyone I know dreads coming to work. Morale is the worst I've ever seen at any job. People with more than 20 years of experience were layed off and replaced with any old contractor off the street. Associates spend their days training new contractors. Management is clueless to what is happening and keeps saying that things are working. There is a double standard about work hours and work ethic. Some people do tons of overtime and are stressed out constantly, while others barely understand their job functions and are rarely at their desks, yet are promoted. HR provides no help in finding quality contractors; they just want you to pick anyone. It used to take a long time to get hired here. Not anymore. It's almost impossible to advance, and now management will just tell you you're doing a different role even if it's not what you were hired to do. I'm surprised there haven't been lawsuits since they are involved in illegal hiring practices since the recent layoffs.

headline: Golden handcuffs
pros: Beautiful campus, competitive pay, good retirement
cons: No advancement opportunities, lack of diversity (very few minorities in leadership), lack of consistent vision -- many territory wars

headline: They are the standard I compare other employment experiences with
pros: Great Benefits.  Insurance, retirement package, bonuses, in office subsidised cafeteria, culture - employee & family picnic, tickets to local events, etc.  The greatest take away in my opinion was the financial and investment knowledge that I gained in the course of learning to assist shareholders has provided tremendous personal benefits too.
cons: Very flat organization, more lateral growth opportunities vs. upward mobility.  The overtime requirements were a personal issue for me at family rearing stage of life.

headline: Great, Talented People - Difficult to Advance
pros: Capital Group is staffed with wonderful, professional, and talented people. I feel honored to count myself amonst them. The benefits are amazing and they offer plenty of training and job resources. The immediate and senior management I encountered stood by their "open door" policy and were always approachable. CG is a world class employer with a strong and distinct corporate culture. Business decisions are made in comprehensive, thoughtful, and thoroughly vetted ways.
cons: Advancement opportunities are difficult to come by. Opportunities are there; however moving up in the organization takes time, patience, and strict adherence to the "CG way," i.e. living the Capital Group culture. The organization also will never be blazing trails but rather leadership has a tendency to get mired down in traditional, conventional ways/ideas. This conservative nature is not necessarily a con but I mention it because prospective associates should be aware that the CG wheels turn quite predictably and slowly.

headline: After 20 yrs, I would not have left had I not moved!!!
pros: Capital's culture is one of collaboration, teamwork and respect. The Executive Team is made up of super smart, thoughtful individuals. Your ideas are welcomed. Work-life balance is encouraged. The benefits are very generous.
cons:
The Investment Group is sometimes perceived as being treated like "prima donnas" opposed to the Admin side of the business. To this I say, remember who brings in the business and why you are still employed. 

Separately, a few roles are hard to break out of and HR can sometimes be an obstacle.

headline: Great company
pros: The training program was excellent.  They provided a great atmosphere with plenty of perks.
cons: I lived an hour away, so the commute ended it for me.  Nothing wrong with the company.

headline: Great!
pros: Excellent compensation package and work/life balance.
cons: Limited upward mobility.  Lack of formal associate development programs.

headline: Biggest joke on earth
pros: Retirement benefits were great, medical were better than average back then. Paid for my MBA. Bonuses are great.
cons: Anyone with an opinion other than management's is branded as a trouble maker. All you are expected to do is come in and agree with management. Don't form your own opinion or step on anyone's toes and you will go far. CG boasts about their work/life balance but god forbid you need to take time off, and they will find a way to make sure you are not meeting expectations and withhold your bonus. I was with the company for more than 10 years and realized that as long as I was unwilling to kiss management's butt, I would never move. So I opted to go somewhere where my opinions and suggestions were valued. Management asks for ideas and then takes the credit for themselves, which in turn lowers morale. The way the layoffs were handled in 2098-2009 were poor at best,  and that is the point where I lost all respect for the company.

headline: Wonderfl experience
pros: Lovely environment to work in.  Coworkers are friendly and knowledgeable.  Salary is ok for this area.  Good parking.  Gourmet café for employees.  Green company
cons: More permanent positions should be available.  18 month contract resulting in me looking for permanent work once the contract expires.

headline: Great place to make a career!
pros:
Opportunities for career advancement and changes
Great training
Management willing to listen and actually hear issues and take steps to remedy

I've worked for capital for 19 years, and I've had the opportunity to hold numerous positions and fill many different roles within the organization.  There aren't many companies out there that will give you the chance to find roles that meet all of your strengths.  Capital is the first "real" job I ever held, and I've heard the horror stories from others with other large corporations.  With an open mind and a drive to do great work, you can go far with Capital.
cons: Hours can sometimes be long due to nature of work and staffing issues

headline: 3 stars
pros: Good work life balance. Benefits (health insurance, MRP, vacation) are great.
cons: Slow moving company. Top heavy with middle managers. Little career mobility. Most employees seemed to be stuck in their roles. Low pay compared to industry standards.

headline: Golden Handcuffs are not worth the underhanded politically correct environment with no technical growth potential
pros: Salary and Bonus are good if you are in managements good graces. 15% company contribution to 401K is unbeatable
cons: Stifling Technical environment where soft skills and brown nosing is more important to management than technical performance. Be prepared to always be smiling, and telling them what they want to hear. Honesty is not valued unless it can be given with inappropriate stroking and coddling.

headline: Cultural change
pros: Good benefits, nice coworkers, office furnishings
cons: Mismanaged, competitive environment, highly political

headline: Good company to work for
pros: American funds has a positive culture that promotes cooperation. There is an open door policy with upper management and everyone seems genuinely happy to be there. Depending on location, there is opportunities for advancement as evidenced by the many associates that have worked there for 5-10 years and more. Health benefits are slightly above par.
cons: Overtime can be very taxing on the employees as they are regularly required to work 2+ hrs of OT a week. Some departments require a clear vision as to what their objective and responsibilities are. Salary is an unspoken topic because it ranges vastly depending on associate. Employee recognition is purely superficial.

headline: Great Employer, Unusual Company Culture
pros: The package offered are competitive. High bonuses. Odd mix of generous employee perks.
cons: Innovation is actively discouraged. The company runs on status quo and imitation of competitors. I would describe the company culture as insecure. For many at CG, this is actually a pro, not a con.

headline: Great culture, great environment, great conditions
pros:
- Amazing work environment: there is a real culture of respect and ethics in the way business is done.
- Great life balance. Workload is decent. Although you are expected to deliver strong performances, you work days and nights
- Very competitive packages
- The company is a good "citizen" through its generous donations to local associations.
cons: - Lack of career opportunities

headline: Not a bad place to work
pros: Compensation package is very good.
cons: Culture is changing.  Trying to outsource as much work as possible.

headline: Interesting...challenging.
pros: Reputation of company. Some great people
cons: Accountability stops at certain level in the organization. The lack of accountability makes movement difficult

headline: Great place to work
pros: At American Funds the compensation is good and you're treated fairly. The culture is relaxed and management is very approachable. They are extremely sensitive about not offending anyone, so if you like to tell dirty jokes at work this probably isn't the company for you.
cons: Because American Funds makes decisions through consensus, it can take a long time to implement a new idea. It can also be very secretive; if, one morning, the person that sits next to you is gone and their desk packed up, you'll just be told that they "no longer work for the company." Don't ask any more questions, or you'll be seen as a troublemaker.

headline: Slow pace with people looking for retirement and not career advancement.
pros: Good pay and overall work schedule.
cons: No opportunities for advancement.  Poor communication between managers and departments.

headline: Not the place for thriving, educated young professionals.
pros: Internal training, no experience necessary.  Free coffee and milk. Cafe on site.
cons: No opportunity for advancement. Only "lateral movement" throughout company.  Management lacks knowledge and experience.  Required overtime nearly every week resulting in 5-10 extra hours.  Set schedule that you must follow minute by minute.

headline: A rewarding and fun experience
pros: Excellent working offices and working conditions
cons: Culture can be resistant to change

headline: great
pros: flexibility, positions, online access, people
cons: n/a, hours available, n/a, n/a, n/aa

headline: Good benefits, terrible management.
pros: Good retirement plan. Salaries aren't particularly competitive within the industry, but fine. Offices are attractive and comfortable. If you get a decent manager (although they don't last long), you can get some good, productive work done, with a minimum of drama.
cons: Too many managers, with no real work to do. They get hooked on the latest fads they read about, and shove them down everyone's throat; none of which makes the work better, but merely fills time. The managers need to be given real work, not instructed to find busy work that interferes with the real work. During the recession of 2008-2009, the organization, which up to then boasted of loyalty to staff, laid off enormous swaths of people, some of whom had devoted the bulk of their working years to CG.

headline: In the beginning I enjoyed the atmosphere, then each there after my disinterest increased.
pros: The employees were nice to work with.
cons: Some upper management were incompetent.  The pay was minimal for the amount of work you had to do, and for the rude financial advisors you had to deal with.  Policies were constantly changing, and you were micro-managed on a daily basis.

headline: Good organization, take care of its people
pros: functional, humanity, well organized, good benefit, work life balance
cons: not very innovative, move slowly

headline: More focus on investor and financial advisor satisfaction than employee development and work/life balance.
pros: Generous retirement benefits, nice office space
cons: Decreasing work/life balance, lack of opportunities for "moving up", excessive required overtime

headline: Not the same company it was 5 yes ago
pros: Benefits are great and affordable
cons: No consistency in management. Progress depends on who your TM is

headline: Capital Group Companies is a good place
pros: Capital Group Companies is a good place
cons: Capital Group Companies could be a better place, like all places

headline: This is a great company, with great perks, benefits and people.
pros:
*Pay well for good work
*Fantastic people
*Good benefits and perks
cons:
*Culture has changed somewhat in the past couple years
*Advancement not always possible

headline: Rewarding
pros: Excellent training program. Ongoing training for employees. Full support from management.
cons: At a certain point, associates reach a plateau and there is not much room for growth after that is hit. At that point, the position feels a monotonous and less challenging. Spending all day taking queue calls gets old very quickly. In Scottsdale, the opportunities were very limited to taking calls.

headline: Good place to work at end of your career or if you are not looking to move up
pros: Very good benefits -- bonuses and retirement plan
cons: Can take forever to get promoted.  You could be there 20 years and still not make it to management.

headline: Great corporate values, but little room for growth in certain sites
pros: Awesome people!  Great benefits.
cons: Little to no advancement opportunities in certain locations.  The organization is very flat, so depending on the department you are in and the state of the market, there may be few opportunities to move up.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Friendly culture at the office. They have great benefits like time off is about 21 days I think. Bonus vacation every five years there. . Most people are willing to help and are respectful. Good vacation time and maternity leave. Depending on the department,no micro management.  Managers care about your success as well. This is one of the most respected mutual fund companies around so it'smore likely that the advisers Will take your phone call but still challenging. Competitive pay. Great retirement plan. They really want to see that their employees retire well. Some of the smartest people and hardest workers I've ever met
cons: Communication about changes  are getting better but still lacking from management.

headline: Capital Group archaic IT systems and consensus bound decision makers.
pros: Nice new offices, grounds and great cafeteria
cons: Strange Zen consensus conformity culture

headline: Don't Trust Anyone!
pros: Benefits, commute, building, furniture, carpet, chairs, break rooms, cafe, parking structure.
cons: Extremely dysfunctional culture.  Social clicks are more important than actual work contribution.  They do not value independent thought or contribution.  It is all about the “borg” collective.  Think outside the box or challenge the “collective” and they will manage you out; regardless of your performance.

headline: Long ...
pros: Benefits, Training, Respect, Retirement and
cons: Work/Life Balance, Too Much Overtime, No Vacation Time allotted

headline: Conservative, polite, generous
pros: A privately owned and conservatively managed company that strives to do things the right way for customers.  A polite culture.  A sense of fairness.  Benefits are good and people are treated well for the most part.
cons: Can feel bureaucratic and slow moving at times.  Too many meetings.  Sometimes people are too polite.

headline: Capital Group is an excellent place to work
pros:
the people are wonderful
the technologies are current 
the environment is pleasant and the facilities are outstanding
cons:
IT contractors are rarely converted to employees
IT contracts are tentative... contractors are disposable assets

headline: Excellent company, sub-par department
pros: Great benefits, excellent work environment overall
cons: The company is behind on hiring so the Customer Service department ("Shareholder Services") has a lot of required over time.  Also, the management needs to do a better job of helping associates know about the resources available to them.

headline: Stay away -- compensation is good, the you're working with snakes
pros: Pay is above average and facilities are very beautiful
cons: Highly political environment with significant in-fighting within leadership resulting in competing priorities.  Turf wars due to many leadership positions being hired from outside the company versus internal promotions.  Each no leader is trying to make their mark on the organization with little attention to the broader goals and objectives

headline: Project Manager
pros: Benefits, compensation, opportunities, and bonuses
cons: Middle managers don't always see beyond the Capital Group world.

headline: Good starting point
pros: Good training program. Good way to learn knowledge of the mutual fund industry. Also a good way to get into the customer service industry.
cons: Everything second of everything you do is closely monitored and timed. When you are on the clock there is no down time. Break and lunch times are closely monitored. You are always being watched. All of your work is checked by peers and you have to check your peers work for quality assurance (which is good) but every little mistake you make is documented and counts against you in reviews and for pay increases. After the first year I only got a 3% raise, and I was considered a high quality performer.

headline: Sr client service re
pros: Great associates, vacation policy and retirement benefits
cons: Call center environment, required overtime and yearly shift changes.  Life/work balance is gone

headline: It's a Living Hell
pros:
Good benefits
Telecommuting options
Nice cafeteria
Agile Methodology adoption
cons:
Very slow to no upward mobility. 
Very few technologists in mid and upper management.
The HR Department is the worst HR. One HR lady helping NAD associates talks so much that you will get fed up and rather not seek her out. HR seems to try always play safe and issues bought up with HR are NOT kept confidential.
The Management Team is in useless meetings most of the day with no productive outcomes.
Associates are swamped with too many meetings and conflicting priorities.
Managers are unable to help team members to prioritize their work as they themselves are under immense pressure from Sr Management to do "more with less". Some team managers work very long hours 13+ hours putting pressure on their teams.
The NAD IT teams are so lean that most people including managers seem burnt out. 
In the NAD IT department the degree and expectation to multitask has reached unacceptable proportions but the NAD Sr Management is unrelenting in overloading the associates.
When new Projects come up NAD Sr Management instead of properly planning resources will move resources without any thought and without  looking into impacts to other projects. Team managers are forced to give up their resources for "strategic projects" and other associates are then overloaded.
Incompetent people get ahead by "being friends" with the right people in management.
Most associates seem depressed and find it hard to come in to work but we keep coming back for another day in hell to collect our bonus.
If there is a living hell you can find it here at CG IT. Can't wait to get out of this hell.

headline: Mostly ups but some downs
pros: Some great managers that really care. I was given growth opportunities and learned a lot. Benefits and pay were great, building was nice and overall environment was nice to go to work in each day.
cons: Very high expectations of employees. HR is kind of pretentious. Although some managers try to be laid back, fun and understanding others are stuck up, rigid and rude. Hard to move up in the company and build rapport with these managers.

headline: Conservative and Steady
pros: The benefits can't be beat, especially their retirement for the staff. Capital Group is conservative compared to other financial institutions, but they try to keep their employees happy. There's even a fun committee to help plan company-wide events.
cons: Some managers are too micro-managers, which made the work environment very difficult. Salary is on the "low" side of the industry, but the bonuses are generous, balances out.

headline: CG employs great people, but the company needs to recognize low morale and dis-engaged associates.
pros:
-Smart and helpful associates
-Excellent retirement benefits
-Pay is ok
-Bonuses are nice
cons:
-CG associates are spread thin and the company runs lean.  It is more evident recently with initiatives that enforce running the business economically.  It's a shame because people work hard with no work/life balance. 
-Morale is low across the board.
-Only a handful of advancement opportunities.

headline: Not what it used to be
pros: good financial management company overall,
cons: IT organization is in disarray.

headline: Happy to be from Capital Group
pros: Really nice campus in Irvine.  Good salaries, bonuses, and deferred compensation plan.  Casual attire everyday.  Good level of investment in technology.
cons: The back office functions, especially the information technology organization, tried to mimic the consensus approach to investing of the fund management teams, but never really succeeded.

headline: it's good so far!
pros: nice people, good environment, good work schedule
cons: required overtime...but everyone gets those can't complaint

headline: Great company with unique culture
pros:
Associate relations
Collaboration
Respect for individuals
Coaching model
Specific development conversations
Flexibility
Competitive salary and bonus structure
Relaxed dress code
Departmental communication is consistently good
Managing change - extensive training
cons:
Working in the grey
Career advancement opportunities are limited
Turning into a true call center and work not as varied as it once was
Work/life balance with required OT does not seem as important

headline: Evolving to stay competitive
pros:
-Great people
-Above average pay and benefits
cons:
-Changing so quickly not sure who is doing what
-Lack of organizational charts made sense when company was flat but now there are so many layers and changing monthly it is very difficult to keep up with who is doing what
-Increasing difficulty getting tasks done because everyone is filled to capacity
-Competing priorities at task level -resources overbooked

headline: Team oriented culture
pros: Lots of teamwork, feedback-based performance reviews.
cons: The "ladder" for advancement is not clear.. it's difficult to figure out what you need to do to get promotions.

headline: Rely heavily on temp labor.
pros: Great company;  loved my co-workers!   I think I lucked out though.
cons: Impossible to get hired into as a temp to perm......no such thing.  Max work time is one year.

headline: Good people
pros: The people you work with are open minded and friendly. Collegial respect is a nice feature. Because the organization is large, you will have ample opportunity to meet lots of people.
cons: Be prepared for a lengthy interview process. The screening process is rigorous, but the reason for that is to assemble a group of people who work well together.

headline: Team Manager
pros: Good company for pay and benefits.
cons: One must experience it for themsleves

headline: The only reason I stayed at this soul crushing job so long was because they had great benefits.
pros:
Great Benefits
Vacation and sick time
cons: They don't value their employees

headline: Company is struggling to find new direction
pros:
Good benefits
Troops on the ground want to do the right thing
Good compensation
Nice facilities and physical environment
Pleasant colleagues
cons:
In some pockets, vendors have stronger influence than associates
Lacks strategic vision: seems to be following other players in the industry rather than innovating
Several layers of management and very outdated technology makes it almost impossible at times to get work done
Due to many years of micromanagement, very difficult to transfer and share tribal knowledge between groups

headline: Short term very good (15 years ago) but very disappointing as time passed.
pros: Initially very good pay and benefits. Solid management team at first. Highly trained and intelligent workforce.
cons:
Senior Manager under went some physical challenges and it dramatically changed his judgement and ability to lead. Took a very long time (5 to 8 years) for the business to address and made everyone's life miserable in the mean time. New management team came in and did what they always do - get rid of the current team and replace with cronies from their old jobs.  
Special bonus numbers were reneged upon for certain entire management levels but were communicated as individual performance problems. We learned about the special bonus being removed for an entire level of managers from other affected managers at the same level , not by our direct leaders.
Benefit promises made pre-retirement were not kept. Health insurance numbers that they show you to plan your retirement immediately change as soon as you retire. Costs went up by 60% in two years while active employees were largely unaffected. I was told to expect this to continue for retirees (25-30% a year).

headline: Capital Group Companies Employee Review
pros: Good to employees, pretty good benefits
cons: No upward mobility because people rarely leave

headline: The Private Client Group is a mess
pros: Compensation is above average in the industry.
cons: Senior management is detached from line issues.  Middle management are a bunch of robots.   The New York office is completely dysfunctional, unhelpful and rude.   I would never hire from this pool of ....

headline: A tiger is a lovely creature, until it turns on you and eats your face......
pros:
The firm's strive for mediocrity allows people to gain extremely long tenures without having to actually perform.

No real caps on spending mean expenses aren't an area of focus - - for those above a certain level.
cons:
The firm's arrogance cannot be overstated.

If you want to get the best out of yourself, avoid CG like the plague!

headline: Good benefits, low pay, stiff work environment
pros: The company prides itself on benefits to employees including retirement savings and other on site benefits, maternity leave...  Training program was excellent.
cons: Similar experience/jobs at other companies paid well more than them.  The work environment was extremely stiff and difficult to work in.  If I left my desk(bathroom, fax machine) I felt as if I was being watched every time.  After finishing training about 20 minutes early on one occasion, we were taken tot the HR waiting room to wait.  20 minutes later someone arrived and said that we "could leave" once it was 5pm.  The environment was so bad 3 of 8 new hires elected to leave during training.  Once training was complete and after working a short time one rep put in a 2 week notice because they had another offer.  They were asked to leave on the spot that day.

headline: Great culture, great people but slow progression
pros: I enjoyed the flat culture as well as working with intelligent and friendly associates from all over the world.
cons: Career progression was slow. My manager was more focused on executing his road map for the team rather than developing the strengths of his associates.

headline: Truly unique culture and support work environment
pros: Main reason is culture; CG is all about it the right way and just simply being nice to each other.  The company is very strong and consistent, its been around for 80 years.  Its a very cushy place to work, with great benefits and morale.
cons: In some way CG is very progressive, but in some ways too old fashioned.  The company can take collaboration too far, where it slows projects to a crawl.  Sometime you have to please so many different departments, the end product is neither fresh or exciting.  Also, the company is against org charts for some reason, so its really hard to find the people you need to talk to.  CG is not a lean organization, they have layers upon layers of management and decision makers.

headline: Outstanding Place to work
pros:
Benefits
Pay
Employee perks (free event tickets were given away to employees. concerts, football, etc.)
Master Retirement Plan
cons: Getting laid off after the economy tanked in 2008.  For me, there were no cons working for American Funds.

headline: Culture of criticism and negativity
pros: The Capital Group offers good compensation and benefits, but it's not worth the pound of flesh they exact from your life and sanity.
cons: It's all about what you might have done wrong in the perception of some unknown critic.  Newer employees are under a microscope, and are considered defective until proven perfect.  I have known over a dozen people who have worked there who corroborate my experience, so I know it's not a case of my judgement being clouded.  I also know of some who thrive there, so if you like to swim with piranhas, this may be your cup of tea.

headline: Disappointing, micro-managed, backward, slow, low pay
pros: Nice offices and they don't work too long hours, that's about it really
cons:
This is a very old, backward organisation that only exists because of large clients that they have had for many years. They refuse to change and update their products (they still don't use derivatives), their systems and their processes. A depressing place to work where even changing the paper in the copier needs 5 levels of authorisation. 

Career progression is very limited. To get a decent investment role you need to come in on the grad programme and only ever work there.

Managements outlook is very narrow and insular as most have never worked for any other organisation.

And to put the nail in the coffin, bonuses (outside of the investment managers and marketing) have a strict cap at a very low level.

headline: Capital has a great depth of culture. People here want the best for you and they bring the best out of you
pros: Industry leaders, People, Work-life balance,
cons: Very US centered, Large organizations change happens slowly

headline: Great place to learn about mutual funds
pros: The Master Retirement Plan is a tremendous benefit. Covered parking. Nice amount of vacation. Good insurance plans.  Bonus structure generous
cons: No on-site child care. Some departments may be a bit understaffed causing high workload on the people in the department. Some positions may require extra worktime on top of 40 hour work week

headline: I won't leave anytime soon
pros: Bonus, benefits, and wages are excellent
cons: Slow to grow due to current nationwide financial status

headline: Disappointing
pros: Nice facilities and work enviroment and decent wage and bonus structure, especially for management. .
cons: Huge disconnect between management and the rank and file employeed. Management style is subjective to the manager thus creating a deviation in factors considered for performance management. Definite age bias and lack of promotion for older workers.  Human Resources is probably the worst in the industry.

headline: The focus has always been the culture and the associates.
pros: The culture here is one that fosters growth and loyalty.  There are no stars, and egos are always kept in check.
cons: The competitive market pressures force Capital to evolve, and changes are happening too rapidly and management flounders with the execution.  Credibility, especially with new managers who don't have strong operational knowledge, is suffering.  Hence, they have a hard time inspiring and leading contributing to high turnover rate in departments that used to pride itself in low turnover.

headline: A unique place, and it starts at the top.
pros: The quality of people, at all levels of the organization, is extraordinary. There's a strong sense of purpose, mission and community. The leadership team is focused on long-term success, and backs that up with consistent long-term decision-making.
cons: No company is perfect. At times, decision-making can seem slow, particularly for newer associates. The aura of politeness can also get in the way of frank debate and discussion. Overall, though, recent years have seen significant change for the better with regard to both.

headline: Great Company to Work For
pros: Awesome benefits and company culture
cons: Management shows some favoritism towards employees.

headline: One of the best places to work for!!!
pros: Amazing place to work and meet some of the smartest people within investments
cons: Can't think of any thing

headline: Great place to work
pros: Tremendous transparency-opportunities to mingle with leadership at the highest levels. The lack of ceilings is extraordinary.
cons: Sometimes the culture is slow to change and middle management isn't as accountable as they could be.

headline: Overall, my experience was positive.
pros: The benefits were really great!
cons: It is a little slow to change positions or get promotions in the mid-level jobs.

headline: Where you want to retire
pros: Good work/life balance. Up to 5 weeks vacation + 1 bonus week after 5 years of employment. Solid bonus structure. If you are at the end of your career, stop here.
cons: No room for advancement past Management level. Global organization with no opportunities for cross country assignments. CIO is average leader at best. She wanted Capital to be just like "any other organization". Ask the recruiter why so many Managers and Sr. Managers have left in the last 12 months.

headline: agreed, used to be great, now ordinary employer
pros: The pay is reasonable for the position, still have decent benefits and bonuses paid twice a year.
cons: There are too many team managers and senior managers for the number of employees they "supervise".  There is no clear path/direction to actually advance in the company.  There are lots of "opportunities" which do not develop into a promotion or a raise.  The wonderful perks have gone away year by year.  The bonuses are not rising as the company's profit is back on the rise.  They are so far behind in technology, that it is now a mad rush to catch up and expect associates to embrace it and promote it.

headline: Proud to work at Capital.
pros: Fair, honorable, well respected in the industry, bright and nice co-workers, challenging and fulfilling work.
cons: Difficult interview process, high stress.

headline: Highly Bureaucratic and Slow Moving
pros: It's a privately owned firm with a good reputation that tries to invest in technology and resources for its employees.
cons: The company is so large it has lost all ability to be dynamic, which is crucial in the changing environment of the industry.  Decisions take eons to make as they go through several committees and levels of management.  They have so many unnecessary levels of management throughout the company as a result of promoting for the sake of promoting - they will make someone a manager of a department that the person has never worked in nor has any knowledge of.  The place is run like a government agency, and I mean that in the worst way possible.

headline: A company that takes care of its employees but offers no challenge
pros:
Great benefits package
Nice campus
Very stable
This is the place to be if you never want to have to think again. Camp out, get your crappy raise every year, don't argue with management and collect your bonus and MRP.
cons:
Focus on outsourcing and integrating 3rd party products in IT. 
Very boring work
Very restrictive 'standards' implemented across IT limits the amount of creativity and control you will have to deliver solutions to your users.

headline: Golden Handcuffs
pros: Very good salary, retirement plan, bonus and benefits.  Top notch co-workers.  Beautiful facilities.  A retirement plan that will not be found at 99% of other companies.
cons: Little ability for advancement, despite what they will tell you when interviewing.  Top heavy management.  As an organization, slow to react and adapt to the changing marketplace.  The CG culture and "core values" are emphasized relentlessly, despite spotty adherence by Senior Management.  Happiness and success at this company will depend on what department you are in.  Some departments and managers are great - like most companies it is a mixed bag.  It has changed a lot (as would be expected) over the last 5 years, and still seems in search of a clear strategy and brand.

headline: Management Overwhelmed
pros: Benefits are great relative to base pay, fellow associates and managers are generally nice and easy to work with, and initial job training gets you ready for entry level positions
cons: Inconsistent promotion process with mid-level managers having too much input and subjectivity. Business processes and platforms are out of date which make day to day responsibilities more difficult to complete. Workforce in various departments are well understaffed, creating a volatile environment management is not equipped to handle. Scheduling a vacation (months in advance) has become near impossible due to this staffing issue, and management does not intend to alleviate this pressure by hiring more people. They fear an eventual erosion in the fiduciary or directed custodian marketplace (with broker/dealers taking control of their accounts due to more stringent SOX regulation) will leave the business unit overstaffed which is understandable, but need to find more creative solutions in the meantime (such as sharing work with sister subsidiaries).

headline: Great company.
pros: Great company and benefits. Respectful people.
cons: Very Structured. Too big for anyone ambitious. No job growth potential in Indianapolis.

headline: Very large and organized company, but behind the times technologically.
pros:
-Great benefits/salary
-Extensive training
-Professional environment
-Great facilities
-Good advancement opportunities
-Knowledgeable associates
-Large pool of assets enables them to be fully staffed
cons:
-Technologically behind the times compared to other firms in the mutual fund industry
-Focus on their internal culture is so strong that it some times hinders innovation
-Can be a very political environment depending on who you report to

headline: Corporate culture and strong reputation
pros: Compensation are great, training are provided during your career to make you progress. Internal mobility and international opportunities are offered. Relationships with supervisors are open with a strong sense of transparency. Work/life balance is respected.
cons: Selectivity to enter the company is very strong.

headline: Great benefits, no clear path for advancement
pros: Capital group offers excellent medical and retirement benefits. Vacation benefits are misleading as they are based upon work volumes, which makes vacation around the holidays difficult.
cons: There is no clear path for advancement at Capital Group. Finding the motivation to work had everyday is almost impossible as there in no incentive to work hard.

headline: Glorified call center job with no room to advance. Glad to be out of there!!
pros: Benefits very good, but they have to be or they would not be able to retain employees. Pay was average. You are given the proper materials and tools to perform your job. Office setting was nice and always clean. Underground parking was nice for the summer months.
cons: Massive amounts of micro-managing in this position. It gradually got worse over the years to the point of frustrating the majority of the employees. The company appears to be focusing more on the bottom line than their employees. Very stats driven and phone time is the majority of your day. Little room for advancement (espcially in the AZ office). VERY stuffy in the office. Not a lot of people smiling. Most leave their sense of humor at home or don't have one at all. Still unable to figure out exactly what senior management did all day at the office. Same goes for team managers. The ONE major responsibility for them was to write the employees reviews each year. In addition, team managers frown on taking supervisor calls and will normally pass it off to an associate on their team to handle it. Most team managers were hired with little to no experience in the mutual fund industry. It really shows. Even after years on the job they have no clue what we are talking about.

headline: Almost cultish and everyone is a cheerleader for the company, but overall a great place to work
pros: Beautiful campus, lots of perks, good benefits
cons: overly structured and not as efficient in my work as I'd like to be

headline: ITG Director
pros: People, collaborative environment.  Nice place to work.
cons: Ongoing changing environment.  Less loyalty to associates than in the past.

headline: Capital Group is a great place to work.
pros: The salary and benefits are generous, and there are some truly wonderful and very smart  people who work there. As far as corporate jobs go, you don't get much better than Capital. Getting hired is very tough. I went on an endless series of interviews before finally getting the nod.
cons: The pay is very good, and along with it comes very high expectations. Once you achieve manager or higher, expectations are commensurate with your salary. On the one hand, you can't blame them - they deserve to get their money's worth, and they do. But the pace can be hard to sustain at times. Upper management actively seeks and develops talent, but only if you're lucky enough to be one of the "chosen". If not, it's hard to change perception once it sets in. Overall, you need to be smart and you need to bring your "A" game everyday. Work life balance can be tough at times.

headline: American Funds was ok
pros: The people I worked alongside, adn teh managers I reported to, were all great people.
cons: The salary was below competetive.  Every time I requested a review with a salary increase, the request was denied.   It wasn't until I resigned that they offered me more money.

headline: The zebra changed it's stripes, unfortunately not for the better...
pros: Solid, finanically secure company with high integrity and client-focused moral compass.  Decisions aren't made lightly and shareholders' interests always come first.  You will always sleep well at night knowing it is highly unlikely they will be headline news tomorrow for doing something unscrupulous or illegal.  Salaries are higher at other firms but combined with employee benefits, the overall comp package ranks in the top quartile.
cons:
No longer value the contributions and loyalty of long-term employees
Don't offer products and services that fit current investment trends
Employee demographics lack cultural diversity, especially in senior management

headline: From Great to Horrible
pros: Great benefits, nice amenities, good work/life balance in the Investment Group, 2 bonuses. A calm work place.
cons: Management here is generally really bad (across most departments). The company culture here used to be great but is declining rapidly. It used to be a joy to come to work, now it's a pain and many people are just collecting a paycheck. There has been an increase in an overall sense of dissatisfaction in the last few years.  It's hard to move up unless you have been here for a really long time and are in good with Senior Management. There is not a lot of rhyme or reason around promotions here, lots of decisions are shrouded in secrecy.  Additionally, managers are well aware of the bleak employment opportunities out there these days and have taken a "take it or leave it" attitude toward employee dissatisfaction. I would recommend working here to someone who needs a paycheck and is not concerned with sharpening skills or moving up. You can easily sail through a 20 year career here not putting forth much effort.

headline: First job out of college, a taste of cubicle life.
pros: Great benefits, great people, great attitude.
cons: Low upward mobility, strict and stiff rules, not exciting.

headline: Yes, change is difficult. Lets be honest.
pros: Overall compensation is top notch. Company direction is like an aircraft carrier making a 180, turning it takes time. Management is better than you think when you look closely. A place for you to grow if you want to, and are willing to push yourself, and I mean really go out on a limb and stop being comfortable. Executive leadership is excellent, and transparent. Management committee communicates frequently.
cons:
CG is changing, and at a wild pace. It's not the change that is really difficult, it's the pace of change. Frankly, some talent has already left voluntarily, and more is likely to follow. But, and there is a big BUT here ... so please read on. The current economic climate and business climate is rough. Assets under management are being pressured, and client mandates lost to competitors. I often find myself saying to fellow associates, "What would you do if you were an owner?" I think sometimes associates forget that we are a privately held business. That means we are in business to do something specific. If you make lemonade and order a big truckload of lemons only to find that 2/3rds are rotten after you've unloaded it, then you can't make any money. I think there is a small bit of entitlement culture at play as well. Some Senior Management would benefit from a shake up too. It's not that most management is out to get anyone, or is intentionally destructive, I don't believe that, rather, some people just are not capable of handling the reins when the 'stuff'
 hits the fan. It's like the reviewers here cannot stop and take a breath, and be objective. If you got up in the morning and went to your job at the local tire shop, are you going to gripe about every lugnut that gets stuck today? Come on people, perspective. Change is tough. Times change. Business cycles sometimes demand rapid change, and that can be painful. This is survival for CG. Yea, outsourcing  sometimes sucks too. But as a long term employee myself, the fact is that it is better for the bottom line for remedial work to be sent offshore instead of paying a high internal wage. This fact is, outsourcing is to the benefit of every single associate, as we are indeed a stakeholder in overall profitability of the company, and our company 'owners' are the most generous folks around, like our founders and their family. They share with the entire associate base, a massive amount of compensation that they could keep all to themselves, but instead, they see the value of the shared sacrifice / shared reward model. Don't forget this, ever, it is a powerful mindset, and can allow you to share in the success of CG too when you being to start thinking like an owner. Look, all the change amounts to tough times internally, and a bit of shaken morale. If you're seeking employment at CG, yes, do your homework. But be able to see the big picture too, not every associate or manager is jaded. Most people I work with work hard, take their job seriously, are true professionals, have total respect for their managers and above, and even know how to have a good time. So now, go re-read the 'Pros'.

headline: Very little advancement opportunities. Either start or end your career here.
pros: Mature organization. Well developed employee training and development plan. Good pay and benefits. Good people (non-Sr Management level) to work with. Private, company with a strong balance sheet. If you are at the end of your career, this is the place to finish your last 10 years.
cons: Hire from the outside rather than promote from within. Culture has changed with new management that was hired in during the last 3 years. It used to be the Sr, Directors would know your name and take time to talk to you. They all moved into one floor and only give townhall updates. No room for advancement.

headline: ch-ch-ch-ch-changes...
pros: thorough job training & on-site cafeteria
cons: constant re-organization of management, job titles & responsibilities

headline: Overall good
pros: At the time I worked at Capital, there was a "family business" attitude.
cons: In the proceeding years, the company was beginning to loose the "family" atmosphere, and became a "big soulless" company.

headline: Great benefits, but work environment is poor.  Some depts at better than others
pros:
Comp and benefits are very good
Peers are great people to work with
cons:
Lack of leadership
Too many meetings about nothing
Managers quick to take credit and to pass blame

headline: Best Compensation and Benefits Plan and Nicest people to work with
pros:
Unparallelled Retirement Contribution with no employee contribution required
Core Values are actually practiced
Nicest people I have ever worked with
cons:
Bureaucracy is intense
Management is continually monitoring everything you say and trying to 'mold' you into what they want you to be, even if it does not fit your personality type.
Political Correctness retards honesty at the cost of innovation

headline: Good
pros: Prime Location, Good Management, Great Friends
cons: Not Trusted after Long Years of Working

headline: Lotsa change but good place to work.
pros:
Pay including bonuses are comparable to other financial services IT positions
Many benefits
International company with diverse associate base
aware of the need to change with economic challenges
Focused on maintaining associate base (avoiding need for job reductions) and increasing efficiency and assets under management.
cons:
A lot of change at once leads to some conflicting priorities
Use of offshore IT partners is strategic but perhaps needs more thought and consideration in some areas
limited advancement opportuities

headline: Relaxed environment
pros: Great benefits, good work life balance.
cons: Not much room for promotions

headline: Consistent culture and integrity
pros: Long tenure, good benefits and home/work balance, associate consideration
cons: May not be the highest compensation

headline: Unless you are applying to work in investment management - Avoid like the plague
pros:
Health benefits.........Great medical, dental and vision....plus they subsidize the costs of some exercise equipment or gym membership......
that is about it
cons:
Vacation-
You get 3 weeks vacation as a first year associate yet they don't tell you its based on a convoluted wait list system that takes into account your rank, seniority and the days or weeks you want off. Most of the time people don't get to use their vacation because they can't get the days off. I had a coworker in tears because she couldn't get time off to see family and she asked for it well in advance.
Management - 
Most managers are unprofessional, power-tripping, and have no idea how to manage themselves let alone anyone else. They are constantly belittling someone for whatever reason they see fit. It is so rampant in the American Funds Shareholder departments that you kind of get used to it. 
Workload -
Workload is relatively simple yet mind-numbing and tedious. The work can be done by someone with only a high school diploma.
Cafeteria -
Supposedly the food is subsidized yet we would get emails every month letting us know they had to raise the prices due to fuel costs and the economy. They run the cafeteria like a for-profit food service. Food is not cheap by any means.
Culture -
You are force fed Capital Group propaganda on a weekly basis. You receive about 3 months of indoctrination and then you follow that up with new meetings and training sessions on a weekly or biweekly basis that is designed to program you to not think for yourself and obey-obey-obey. As ludicrous as this sounds...just ask someone who worked in shareholder services. 
Upward Mobility-
Nearly impossible and most of the time those that get small promotions see pay raises within a dollar or two increase. The smart people try to move horizontally but that doesn't get you very far. I was lucky and I contacted the Investment Group on my own and I was able to land an interview for a  Research Associate
To Add Further Insult -
If you make the 5 year mark they take you to the LA office to see how Capital Groups employees are treated like actual people. They sit you down in a conference room and they bring in people from different groups to tell you how amazing their jobs are only to make you feel smaller. People who went on this 5 year trip went home in tears.

headline: It Depends on What Business Group You Land In
pros:
- Great retirement plan (FYI - you're not fully vested until 6 years)
- Great healthcare
- Nice offices with amenities (at least if you work in a building w/investment group offices)
- Stability - you're not likely to suddenly lose your job
- Good comp with multiple bonuses / incentives throughout the year
- Big company - possible to move around, sort of.  I quit, but *was* offered a position in another business group. 
- Civil office culture - yelling & open disrespect aren't tolerated
- Good coworkers - some really lovely people work there.

If you're looking for a stable corporate job where you punch a clock and don't need to think independently, it's probably a good fit for you.
cons:
- Employee satisfaction varies dramatically depending on business group and manager.
- Not a meritocracy - most places aren't entirely, of course, but it seems especially true at Capital.
- Growth is often not possible because most associates are overburdened with volume of tasks.
- Intelligence and honesty are not valued.  Being able to play the game is.

They promote and emphasize growth in theory, but in practice advancement is a result of politicking and interpersonal strategy. Get in good with the boss = get your workload reduced + get handed opportunities for exposure.  I saw this happen at all levels, from senior management all the way down to admin assistants.

Also - globally speaking - they're going through some big changes, so it may be a little extra bumpy for a while.

headline: A good company to work for
pros: Benefits are great. Associates are treated with respect.
cons: The organization has gone through several changes in the past few years.

headline: Good Pay, Poor Advancement, No Leadership
pros: Pay is good. bonus occurs 2x a year
cons: Bonuses are considered part of your "base". The bonuses continue to diminish dramatically year over year (net result is lowered overall pay). Company struggles with direction. Annual reviews are performed in the round, by a gathering of managers you don't come in contact with or have little to due with your assignments and how well you perform them..

headline: Amazing place to work.  Best company ever!
pros: I hated leaving American Funds, and only left to relocate.  The benefits, the people, the learning opportunities, the facilities...everything was beyond compare.  I consider myself incredibly lucky to have worked for a company with such high standards.  The interview and selection process was very thorough, which made me feel like I was one of a select few to make it through.  That translated into the fact that I then got to work with some very high quality people who were smart and cared about doing a good job.  What could be better than that?
cons: I've seen some of the cons others have stated about American Funds and I find them rather disturbing.  All I can say is I had a wonderful experience.  It's work people...work is work and if you have to work, this is a great place to do it.  Have some other work experiences and then reflect on your experience at American Funds, and I bet you'll see it in a different light.

headline: Excellent work experience!
pros: I really enjoyed working for American Funds.  The only reason I left was the lack of room for growth. The company has a lot of integrity and the managers were very approachable.  I met a lot of great people there.  The job helped me improve my attention to detail, stress management, and listening skills.
cons: Lack of room for growth (promotions, specifically)

headline: Great Company
pros:
Value all associates
Career advancement opportunities
cons:
Old Technology
team to communicate efficiently
Really hard for company to make any type of changes

headline: Great place to work
pros: The salary was competitive. The employees were very courteous and professional. The offices were very nice. The retirement fund benefits were incredible.
cons: Working in the investment offices was much better than the service offices. After the layoffs in 2009, I hear that the culture has changed in IT.

headline: Great pay, benefits, and culture
pros: The twice a year bonus and the 15% yearly contribution into your retirement plan. The managers are are upbeat and treat the employees fairly. I miss working there a lot. There aren't too many companies out there that pay and treat their employees so well.
cons: They rarely let an employee go so an employee that is not pulling their weight is allowed to stay there for as long as they want/can, which is a disservice to the hardworking people on their team.

headline: Great benefits, great co-workers, tedious work
pros: Great benefits, paid vacation, great work environment, great co-workers
cons: The work is tedious and you will be answering phones for 8 hours a day.

headline: Overall CG is a good company...  However, some business units are better than others
pros:
-Great culture where all Associates are treated with respect.
-Highly competitive compensation package (bonuses, merit & MRP)
-Good work/life balance
cons:
-Highly bureaucratic organization structure
-Bureaucratic structure has led to limited or no upward mobility
-Key decisions are not made swiftly leading to inefficiency and "analysis paralysis"
-Within the Global Institutional Operations (GIO) team, poor portfolio performance led to layoffs and office consolidations
-Elimination of 9/80 work schedule in some business units

headline: Great company, but IT organization has abandoned the culture
pros: Capital Group has a great work life balance, very collaborative, good benefits. The retirement plan is fantastic, and the offices provide a great work environment.
cons: Within IT the focus has shifted to appreciating new blood and subtly encouraging people to leave. There is no sense of trust within IT in regards to the senior leadership. The company should be more open to telecommuting, 4/40 weeks, etc.

headline: Overall good place to work...
pros: Capital Group offers a great benefits package and places great value on work/life balance - they are progressive when it comes to employee satisfaction in these areas
cons: While they offer the great benefits, there does not seem to be a lot of room for advancement, from the ground up, within the company.

headline: Best company in so-cal to work for
pros:
- High emphasis on core values
- Friendly environment and colleagues/seniors
- Work Life balance
- Effective and being right the first time over efficiency
cons:
- Can seem slow
- Moves based on seniority

headline: The place is dysfunctional... a complete disaster.
pros: compensation and benefits are above average
cons: Senior management is overwhelmed...  They are bleeding assets... archaic technology... a culture resistant to change

headline: Amazing benefits, but the work is complete drudgery.
pros:
+Benefits, including: medical, dental, vision, Master Retirement Plan to which the company contributes 15% of your annual salary, 9 paid holidays per year, 2 weeks paid vacation to start, and many others.
+Beautiful new campus in Irvine built specifically to house this company
+On-site local, sustainable, delicious, and competitively priced meals at the Pacific Cafe (managed by Bon Apetit)
cons:
-rigid daily schedules with minimal to no flexibility (although associates are expected to be flexible and drop whatever they're in the middle of to deviate to another project at the whim of the Work Management dept)
-miles of red tape before employee suggestions are even considered, let alone acted upon
-associates really are treated as "just a number" despite management's efforts to verbally assure them otherwise
-ridiculous double standards (i.e. some people are blatantly allowed to "get away" with more than others)
-sometimes helping another associate from another team will gain that person a promotion (to a title and position higher than yours) while you sit at the same position for several more months (or even years) simply because your manager is not as lenient as the other associate's manager and doesn't "feel you're ready"

headline: Stay Away from the Private Client Service Group
pros: Golden handcuffs of pay and benefits.
cons:
Unfortunately, you will be treated like a slave and nothing will ever be good enough.  10-14 hour days are expected and then when you make mention of the hours that you are working, it becomes a "time management issue" WHAT???  PCS or PIM as it used to be, was focused on excellent customer service and has moved to a $$$ aspect only.  Nobody cares how it gets done or what you 
you are working on.  There is absolutely no recognition for what the associates do on a daily basis, except if you are "buddies" with management.  Morale is at an all time low, due to poor management.  They are losing great employees and nobody will address the issue, management is HORRIBLE.  If I were a client or thinking about becoming a client, think again.  This is not the place it used to be. Go to PIMCO.

headline: Very professional people but relaxed environment
pros: Has Great benefits and compensation
cons: Very busy environment with required overtime at times

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great group of people to work with.  Excellent training for the job you are assigned to do. Pay is also pretty competitive for the industry.
cons: The phones can be very busy during tax season. Not many opportunities for career advancement in the company.

headline: Don't Work Here!
pros: If you work here, open as many accounts for your family and extended family as you possible can.  You can buy the mutual funds at NAV (Class A with no commission) for life, even if you leave the company.  Although pay is lower than most other companies for the work, company provides retirement plan (MRP) of 15% of your salary per year....you vest after 6 years...most employees stay because of this (Golden Handcuffs).
cons: Mediocracy is promoted.  Ideas are accepted only when pushed, and even then, there is no reward when they use them.  In fact, you will suddenly find that you have "personality" issues in your review, which will never go away!.  Stepford wive's mentality.....as long as you always go with the flow and smile no matter what....you will fit in perfectly.  Very clique-ish.  The Golden Handcuffs (see Pros).  It took years for me to re-gain my self-esteem after this job.  Worst place I have ever worked.

headline: Awesome Company!
pros: Benefits start on your first day. Great retirement plan where Capital Group contributes 15% of your annual salary..not match..they GIVE you tge 15%. Training is ongoing, you are constantly learning.
cons: If you work and not up walking around talking, surfing the web or wasting time on sametime..you WILL get promoted. There are some promotions that are more diffuclt to obtain but with 1 on 1's and listening to your Manager and incorporate what your Managers are saying you can work on..you will get promoted. Some team managers and managers just dont care. They are not there to help you succeed. They are on the phone constantly or just gone! Most of them are awesome. I know at my site, the Senior Managers are awesome. They really practice an open door policy.

headline: Great benefits, tough to find advancement opportunities
pros: The benefits at this company are second-to-none.  The health coverage, 15% retirement contribution, and bonus structure (for exempt and exempt-equivalent associates) really are top notch.
cons: It can be difficult to advance beyond a certain point unless you are one of the "chosen" ones.  Also, the pre-sale side caters to the every whim of the sales staff and positions them as the most important people in the building.

headline: What a great place to work - top-notch, first-class, plain great!
pros:
-Positive environment
-Awesome benefits
-Continuous development
-Respect of all employees
cons:
-Lack of growth/advancement opportunities
-Tuition reimbursement program, but no recognition/opportunities after completing degree

headline: If you like boredom.....this is the place for you
pros: pays well, decent benefits, nice campus
cons: no socializing, no talking, no laughing, no enjoyment.  If you are the stereotype accountant - you will love this place.  If you have an inkling of a personality - run!

headline: Nice pay but company is not very progressive in thinking and practices
pros:
- Good salary
- Company has a giving culture, really cares about the community
- upper mgmt was accessible, but one has to be aggressive to access them.
- Very nice retirement plan
cons:
- Lacking a meritocratic culture (outside the investment group)
- Far too many middle managers to be efficient
- Too much bureaucracy
- Not enough work place flexibility; my job could have been done from anywhere in the world with hi-speed internet, but I still had to sit in a cubicle 10 hrs a day
- Not much in the way of internal development for associates

headline: OK
pros: Good pay, compensation and benefits.
cons: Lots of slackers that the companies knows about and prefers to do nothing.

headline: Great People, Good culture, lots of meetings!
pros: Capital group is a huge company with a long history. It's very structured with set procedures for everything. There's always someone to help.  Lots of mutual support. People are great, very dedicated and supportive of each other. The company has great benefits and amenities and people work there for decades, which is extremely rare in a finance company. People love it.
cons: Capital Group tends to  promote from within so hard to work there otherwise. I felt that meetings can be excessive. Sometimes people would have 4-5 meetings in a day, I don't know how stuff was actually getting done.  Because it is so structured there is not as much autonomy as there would be at a smaller firm. You have to really put yourself forward to be recognized.

headline: Great job, not a great career
pros: Great benefits, industry experience, reasonable pay for an entry-level postion.
cons: Environment is very conservative - expect to be taken in a meeting room by a manager if you accidentally let a curse word slip.  You are very micromanaged, your day is planned out for you in 15-minute increments and you'll receive feedback very regularly (sometimes daily or hourly).  Your service levels will be criticized even if you have a valid reason for less phone time, ie a complex client situation that requires review by compliance and/or management.  I was told when I was hired that I could get promoted within the first two years if I performed well, which I was but I was essentially doing the same job, just for a small increase in pay.  There is little room for growth or advancement, if you provide good service they will want you to stay in a CSR position forever.

headline: Let's be real...this is just a call center.
pros: Great benefits, vacation accrual, people are nice and helpful for new associates
cons:
micro managing 
chained to a desk to answer phone calls
no advancement
passive aggressive management
everyone looks miserable at work

headline: Great
pros:
Great benefits and salary
Teamwork greatly encouraged and very effectively managed
Management was very communicative & available 
Performance reviews were very efficient and well done
Efficiency was a priority, but no one was too stuffy or unreasonable
There were a lot of learning opportunities offered and available within the company; but they also encouraged (and paid for!) learning and charitable activities that took place outside the company.
cons: Sometimes there was too much discussion and communication.

headline: good place to work
pros:
good pay
good benefits
nice people
large company
cons: promotions are hard to come by

headline: Best Company I've ever worked for.
pros: Excellent benefits, great coworkers, nice facilities. Great opportunity to learn about the mutual fund industry.
cons: Difficult to advance in Shareholder Services, inconsistency with quality of team managers. The work can be monotonous, at least in SHSV.

headline: Unique culture; leave your egos at the door.
pros: Benefits are great! Everyone is treated with respect. Raising your voice at anyone is unheard of.  Collaborative. Unique. Humbled.
cons: People stay here for years and it's hard to move up in the company. Takes many years to work your way up to management if you weren't a manager prior to joining CG.

headline: Not like it used to be (from what I have heard)
pros:
Very comfortable setting, with many basic food infrastructure (paper plates, plastic ware, snakes, espresso, coffee).
I felt respect from my direct manager.
stable environment.  Not likely to have something unexpected happen to your job.
Nice people on my team, helpful and truly good natured people.
cons:
Directionless.
Too many unnecessary meetings.
Too slow to innovate IT technology
Too difficult too land a job (if your a contractor), doesn't matter if your good.
Too much middle management.
Very little opportunity for growth (at least within the IT departments)
Strange unspoken strictness, and a lack of natural friendly communication between people (strange polices) and too stuffy (overly conservative).

headline: Great place to start a career, but not enough incentive to stay.
pros: The benefits package was a highlight - especially the MRP. Also, the work atmosphere was very casual and open communication was strongly encouraged.
cons: Pay was on the low end of the scale. Also, there was a lot of favoritism shown during promotion periods.

headline: ok
pros: benefits are really good, overall package is good
cons: Provide more growth, transparency plus recognition

headline: You *are* dispensable
pros:
1. The people... the other associates and many of the leaders.
2. Some of the offices have a great atmosphere
3. Many of the senior associates/ portfolio managers / senior analysts have an invested interest in you and helping you grow professionally
4. Great retirement plan
5. Extensive/thorough hiring process -- as a result, a lot of great people recruited.
cons:
1. Moving away from the original values and management style of JL
2. Too many changes at once.  And these monumental changes seem to be implemented by top management without getting input from anyone else (i.e. associates that would be most impacted by the change).  Often times the changes only hinder the associates ability to do their job
3. Despite what they say, there is no "open door" policy.  They do not want to hear feedback unless you are singing their praises and 100% onboard.
4. Mentality is turning into "it's my way or the highway"
5. They seem to be moving into a direction where all employees will become dispensable - where ideas to develop, improve or evolve are disregarded and instead, an assembly line of mass production is put in place.

headline: No Work Life Balance
pros: The company has good benefits. I was always able to get time off when requested.  Worked in a new clean building.
cons: The took away flexible work schedules.  Took away ticket programs.  Managers want more and more work with little chance for advancement.  I you have an MBA you shouldn't be stuck as a Senior Fund Accountant.

headline: You know that famous saying of being between a rock and a hard place, well that's what success is like at Capital.
pros: Pros: Clean campus, reasonably priced cafe, plenty of vacation time, generally very friendly co-workers.
cons: Cons: Excessive overtime, work on almost all holidays due to global business operations, job title does not match job description, favoritism plays a huge part in your success, too many redundant meetings.

headline: I would say my experience was rewarding
pros: When times were good, we could expect 2 bonuses a year. I'm not quite sure whether that is the case anymore. The retirement plan is phenomenal. They offer 10% of your entire annual salary (bonuses included) in addition to your salary and bonuses to invest in your choice of funds managed by the company. They also paid 200/mo to subsidize for public transportation costs. I took the train, never had to drive and slept on my way to and from work. I also like how the company doesn't believe in giving corner offices to any employee for the sake of remaining fair to everyone.
cons: The company seemed to take a 180 when the board hired a CIO from Fannie Mae. She completely destroyed the culture. What was once an open and non-hierarchical organization has become what my coworkers there would now equate to a sweat shop. It would not surprise me if people started addressing one another by numbers rather than by name. The company lost a lot of good people during the downturn and it no longer surprises me that it is no longer ranked one of the best places to work. I'm glad to have been there when the times were  good. It was indeed a rewarding experience, however it has becomes a completely different company.

headline: Being with smart people everyday
pros:
Working with smart people who enjoy being there
Beautiful offices
longevity of other colleagues
cons: Comp starts out slowly and it isn't clear how good it can get

headline: Capital has been great company to work
pros:
Great benefits package
Above average compensation
Very ethical company
Great coworkers and very pleasant work environment
Prestigious company that likes to maintain a low profile
cons:
Limited growth opportunities
Needs a much more well defined associate development program
Way too many meetings in which seemingly no real decisions are made

headline: Dedicated people treating each other decently
pros:
Great facilities and environment
benefit packages - especially retirement
Conservatively managed - privately held
With few exceptions, the talk is walked
cons:
Associates are long tenured which makes upward mobility difficult
Front line associates and management not sufficiently involved with or consulted by senior leaders
